<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">Evolution</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a>
<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">Change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">This article is about evolution in biology. For related articles, see <a href="/wiki/Outline_of_evolution" title="Outline of evolution">Outline of evolution</a>. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Evolution_(disambiguation)" title="Evolution (disambiguation)">Evolution (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For a more accessible and less technical introduction to this topic, see <a href="/wiki/Introduction_to_evolution" title="Introduction to evolution">Introduction to evolution</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content" style="background:transparent;">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="text-align:center;padding-bottom:0;background:#90ee90;font-size:100%;font-weight:bold;">Social implications</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content plainlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Evolution_as_fact_and_theory" title="Evolution as fact and theory">Evolution as fact and theory</a></li>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below hlist">
<ul><li><span class="nowrap"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tree_of_life.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="760" data-file-width="915" decoding="async" height="13" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Tree_of_life.svg/16px-Tree_of_life.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Tree_of_life.svg/24px-Tree_of_life.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Tree_of_life.svg/32px-Tree_of_life.svg.png 2x" width="16"/></a> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Evolutionary_biology" title="Portal:Evolutionary biology">Evolutionary biology portal</a></span></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="185" data-file-width="180" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/16px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/23px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/9/96/Symbol_category_class.svg/31px-Symbol_category_class.svg.png 2x" title="Category" width="16"/> <a href="/wiki/Category:Evolutionary_biology" title="Category:Evolutionary biology">Category</a></span></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Index_of_evolutionary_biology_articles" title="Index of evolutionary biology articles">Related topics</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Evolutionary_biology" title="Template:Evolutionary biology"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Evolutionary_biology" title="Template talk:Evolutionary biology"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Evolutionary_biology&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Evolution</b> is change in the <a href="/wiki/Heredity" title="Heredity">heritable</a> <a href="/wiki/Phenotypic_trait" title="Phenotypic trait">characteristics</a> of biological <a href="/wiki/Population" title="Population">populations</a> over successive generations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> These characteristics are the <a href="/wiki/Gene_expression" title="Gene expression">expressions</a> of <a href="/wiki/Gene" title="Gene">genes</a> that are passed on from parent to offspring during <a href="/wiki/Reproduction" title="Reproduction">reproduction</a>. Different characteristics tend to exist within any given population as a result of <a href="/wiki/Mutation" title="Mutation">mutation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genetic_recombination" title="Genetic recombination">genetic recombination</a> and other sources of <a href="/wiki/Genetic_variability" title="Genetic variability">genetic variation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma2017c_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma2017c-3">[3]</a></sup> Evolution occurs when evolutionary processes such as <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">natural selection</a> (including <a href="/wiki/Sexual_selection" title="Sexual selection">sexual selection</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Genetic_drift" title="Genetic drift">genetic drift</a> act on this variation, resulting in certain characteristics becoming more common or rare within a population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Scott-Phillips_4-0"><a href="#cite_note-Scott-Phillips-4">[4]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_pressure" title="Evolutionary pressure">evolutionary pressures</a> that determine whether a characteristic would be common or rare within a population constantly change, resulting in a change in heritable characteristics arising over successive generations. It is this process of evolution that has given rise to <a href="/wiki/Biodiversity" title="Biodiversity">biodiversity</a> at every level of <a href="/wiki/Biological_organisation" title="Biological organisation">biological organisation</a>, including the levels of <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a>, individual <a href="/wiki/Organism" title="Organism">organisms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Molecular_evolution" title="Molecular evolution">molecules</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Voet2016a_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-Voet2016a-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Scientific_theory" title="Scientific theory">theory</a> of evolution by natural selection was conceived independently by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace" title="Alfred Russel Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a> in the mid-19th century and was set out in detail in Darwin's book <i><a href="/wiki/On_the_Origin_of_Species" title="On the Origin of Species">On the Origin of Species</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-7"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> Evolution by natural selection was first demonstrated by the observation that more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive. This is followed by three observable facts about living organisms: (1) traits vary among individuals with respect to their morphology, <a href="/wiki/Physiology" title="Physiology">physiology</a> and behaviour (<a href="/wiki/Phenotype#Phenotypic_variation" title="Phenotype">phenotypic variation</a>), (2) different traits confer different rates of survival and <a href="/wiki/Reproduction" title="Reproduction">reproduction</a> (differential <a href="/wiki/Fitness_(biology)" title="Fitness (biology)">fitness</a>) and (3) traits can be passed from generation to generation (<a href="/wiki/Heritability" title="Heritability">heritability</a> of fitness).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewontin70_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lewontin70-8">[8]</a></sup> Thus, in successive generations members of a population are more likely to be replaced by the <a href="/wiki/Offspring" title="Offspring">progenies</a> of parents with favourable characteristics that have enabled them to survive and reproduce in their respective <a href="/wiki/Biophysical_environment" title="Biophysical environment">environments</a>. In the early 20th century, other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alternatives_to_evolution_by_natural_selection" title="Alternatives to evolution by natural selection">competing ideas of evolution</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Mutationism" title="Mutationism">mutationism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Orthogenesis" title="Orthogenesis">orthogenesis</a> were <a href="/wiki/Superseded_theories_in_science" title="Superseded theories in science">refuted</a> as the <a href="/wiki/Modern_synthesis_(20th_century)" title="Modern synthesis (20th century)">modern synthesis</a> reconciled <a href="/wiki/Darwinism" title="Darwinism">Darwinian evolution</a> with <a href="/wiki/Classical_genetics" title="Classical genetics">classical genetics</a>, which established <a href="/wiki/Adaptation" title="Adaptation">adaptive evolution</a> as being caused by natural selection acting on <a href="/wiki/Mendelian_inheritance" title="Mendelian inheritance">Mendelian</a> genetic variation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma2017a_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma2017a-9">[9]</a></sup>
</p><p>All <a href="/wiki/Life" title="Life">life</a> on Earth shares a <a href="/wiki/Last_universal_common_ancestor" title="Last universal common ancestor">last universal common ancestor</a> (LUCA)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kampourakis2014_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kampourakis2014-10">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Doolittle_2000_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-Doolittle_2000-11">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> that lived approximately 3.5–3.8 billion years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Origin1_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-Origin1-13">[13]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Fossil" title="Fossil">fossil record</a> includes a progression from early <a href="/wiki/Biogenic_substance" title="Biogenic substance">biogenic</a> <a href="/wiki/Graphite" title="Graphite">graphite</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NG-20131208_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-NG-20131208-14">[14]</a></sup> to <a href="/wiki/Microbial_mat" title="Microbial mat">microbial mat</a> fossils,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-20131113_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20131113-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TG-20131113-JP_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-TG-20131113-JP-16">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AST-20131108_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-AST-20131108-17">[17]</a></sup> to fossilised <a href="/wiki/Multicellular_organism" title="Multicellular organism">multicellular organisms</a>. Existing patterns of biodiversity have been shaped by repeated formations of new species (<a href="/wiki/Speciation" title="Speciation">speciation</a>), changes within species (<a href="/wiki/Anagenesis" title="Anagenesis">anagenesis</a>) and loss of species (<a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">extinction</a>) throughout the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Evolutionary history of life">evolutionary history of life</a> on Earth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma04_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma04-18">[18]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Morphology_(biology)" title="Morphology (biology)">Morphological</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biochemistry" title="Biochemistry">biochemical</a> traits are more similar among species that share a more <a href="/wiki/Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor">recent common ancestor</a>, and can be used to reconstruct <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree" title="Phylogenetic tree">phylogenetic trees</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-The_Cell_by_Panno_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-The_Cell_by_Panno-19">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-20"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_biology" title="Evolutionary biology">Evolutionary biologists</a> have continued to study various aspects of evolution by forming and testing <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hypotheses" title="Hypotheses">hypotheses</a> as well as constructing theories based on <a href="/wiki/Empirical_evidence" title="Empirical evidence">evidence</a> from the field or laboratory and on data generated by the methods of <a href="/wiki/Mathematical_and_theoretical_biology" title="Mathematical and theoretical biology">mathematical and theoretical biology</a>. Their discoveries have influenced not just the development of <a href="/wiki/Biology" title="Biology">biology</a> but numerous other scientific and industrial fields, including <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a>, <a href="/wiki/Medicine" title="Medicine">medicine</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">computer science</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma99_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma99-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p>
<div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History_of_evolutionary_thought">History of evolutionary thought</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_evolutionary_thought" title="History of evolutionary thought">History of evolutionary thought</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/History_of_speciation" title="History of speciation">History of speciation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Lucretius_Rome.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="390" data-file-width="272" decoding="async" height="244" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Lucretius_Rome.jpg/170px-Lucretius_Rome.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bd/Lucretius_Rome.jpg/255px-Lucretius_Rome.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bd/Lucretius_Rome.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Lucretius_Rome.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Lucretius" title="Lucretius">Lucretius</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3355" data-file-width="2293" decoding="async" height="249" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg/170px-Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg/255px-Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg/340px-Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Alfred-Russel-Wallace-c1895.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace" title="Alfred Russel Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4944" data-file-width="4045" decoding="async" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg/170px-Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg/255px-Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg/340px-Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thomas_Robert_Malthus_Wellcome_L0069037_-crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Thomas_Robert_Malthus" title="Thomas Robert Malthus">Thomas Robert Malthus</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="487" data-file-width="398" decoding="async" height="208" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg/170px-Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg/255px-Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg/340px-Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Charles_Darwin_aged_51.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1842, <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> penned his first sketch of <i><a href="/wiki/On_the_Origin_of_Species" title="On the Origin of Species">On the Origin of Species</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_antiquity">Classical antiquity</span></h3>
<p>The proposal that one type of organism could descend from another type goes back to some of the first <a href="/wiki/Pre-Socratic_philosophy" title="Pre-Socratic philosophy">pre-Socratic</a> Greek <a href="/wiki/Philosopher" title="Philosopher">philosophers</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Anaximander#Origin_of_humankind" title="Anaximander">Anaximander</a> and <a href="/wiki/Empedocles#Cosmogony" title="Empedocles">Empedocles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-23"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Such proposals survived into Roman times. The <a href="/wiki/Poet" title="Poet">poet</a> and philosopher <a href="/wiki/Lucretius" title="Lucretius">Lucretius</a> followed Empedocles in his masterwork <i><a href="/wiki/De_rerum_natura" title="De rerum natura">De rerum natura</a></i> (<i>On the Nature of Things</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-24"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-25"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_Ages">Middle Ages</span></h3>
<p>In contrast to these <a href="/wiki/Materialism" title="Materialism">materialistic</a> views, <a href="/wiki/Aristotelianism" title="Aristotelianism">Aristotelianism</a> had considered all natural things as <a href="/wiki/Potentiality_and_actuality" title="Potentiality and actuality">actualisations</a> of fixed natural possibilities, known as <a href="/wiki/Theory_of_forms" title="Theory of forms">forms</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Torrey37_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-Torrey37-26">[26]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hull67_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hull67-27">[27]</a></sup> This became part of a medieval <a href="/wiki/Teleology" title="Teleology">teleological</a> understanding of <a href="/wiki/Nature_(philosophy)" title="Nature (philosophy)">nature</a> in which all things have an intended role to play in a <a href="/wiki/Divinity" title="Divinity">divine</a> <a href="/wiki/Cosmos" title="Cosmos">cosmic</a> order. Variations of this idea became the standard understanding of the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a> and were integrated into <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christian</a> learning, but Aristotle did not demand that real types of organisms always correspond one-for-one with exact metaphysical forms and specifically gave examples of how new types of living things could come to be.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-28"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup>
</p><p>A number of Arab Muslim scholars wrote about evolution, most notably <a href="/wiki/Ibn_Khaldun" title="Ibn Khaldun">Ibn Khaldun</a>, who wrote the book <i><a href="/wiki/Muqaddimah" title="Muqaddimah">Muqaddimah</a></i> in 1377 AD, in which he asserted that humans developed from "the world of the monkeys", in a process by which "species become more numerous".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-kiros_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-kiros-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-Darwinian">Pre-Darwinian</span></h3>
<p>In the 17th century, the new <a href="/wiki/Scientific_method" title="Scientific method">method</a> of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Modern_science" title="Modern science">modern science</a> rejected the Aristotelian approach. It sought explanations of natural phenomena in terms of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Physical_law" title="Physical law">physical laws</a> that were the same for all visible things and that did not require the existence of any fixed natural categories or divine cosmic order. However, this new approach was slow to take root in the biological sciences, the last bastion of the concept of fixed natural types. <a href="/wiki/John_Ray" title="John Ray">John Ray</a> applied one of the previously more general terms for fixed natural types, "species", to plant and animal types, but he strictly identified each type of living thing as a species and proposed that each species could be defined by the features that perpetuated themselves generation after generation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-30"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biological_classification" title="Biological classification">biological classification</a> introduced by <a href="/wiki/Carl_Linnaeus" title="Carl Linnaeus">Carl Linnaeus</a> in 1735 explicitly recognised the hierarchical nature of species relationships, but still viewed species as fixed according to a divine plan.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other <a href="/wiki/Natural_history" title="Natural history">naturalists</a> of this time speculated on the evolutionary change of species over time according to natural laws. In 1751, <a href="/wiki/Pierre_Louis_Maupertuis" title="Pierre Louis Maupertuis">Pierre Louis Maupertuis</a> wrote of natural modifications occurring during reproduction and accumulating over many generations to produce new species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-32"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Georges-Louis_Leclerc,_Comte_de_Buffon" title="Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon">Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte de Buffon</a>, suggested that species could degenerate into different organisms, and <a href="/wiki/Erasmus_Darwin" title="Erasmus Darwin">Erasmus Darwin</a> proposed that all warm-blooded animals could have descended from a single microorganism (or "filament").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> The first full-fledged evolutionary scheme was <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Lamarck" title="Jean-Baptiste Lamarck">Jean-Baptiste Lamarck</a>'s "transmutation" theory of 1809,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> which envisaged <a href="/wiki/Spontaneous_generation" title="Spontaneous generation">spontaneous generation</a> continually producing simple forms of life that developed greater complexity in parallel lineages with an inherent progressive tendency, and postulated that on a local level, these lineages adapted to the environment by inheriting changes caused by their use or disuse in parents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nardon_Grenier91_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-Nardon_Grenier91-35">[35]</a></sup> (The latter process was later called <a href="/wiki/Lamarckism" title="Lamarckism">Lamarckism</a>.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Nardon_Grenier91_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-Nardon_Grenier91-35">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ImaginaryLamarck_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-ImaginaryLamarck-36">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jablonka07_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jablonka07-37">[37]</a></sup> These ideas were condemned by established naturalists as speculation lacking empirical support. In particular, <a href="/wiki/Georges_Cuvier" title="Georges Cuvier">Georges Cuvier</a> insisted that species were unrelated and fixed, their similarities reflecting divine design for functional needs. In the meantime, Ray's ideas of benevolent design had been developed by <a href="/wiki/William_Paley" title="William Paley">William Paley</a> into the <i><a href="/wiki/Natural_Theology_or_Evidences_of_the_Existence_and_Attributes_of_the_Deity" title="Natural Theology or Evidences of the Existence and Attributes of the Deity">Natural Theology or Evidences of the Existence and Attributes of the Deity</a></i> (1802), which proposed complex adaptations as evidence of divine design and which was admired by Charles Darwin.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Darwin91_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Darwin91-38">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sulloway09_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sulloway09-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Darwinian_revolution">Darwinian revolution</span></h3>
<p>The crucial break from the concept of constant typological classes or types in biology came with the theory of evolution through natural selection, which was formulated by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Darwin" title="Charles Darwin">Charles Darwin</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alfred_Wallace" title="Alfred Wallace">Alfred Wallace</a> in terms of variable populations. Darwin used the expression "<b>descent with modification</b>" rather than "evolution".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-40"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> Partly influenced by <i><a href="/wiki/An_Essay_on_the_Principle_of_Population" title="An Essay on the Principle of Population">An Essay on the Principle of Population</a></i> (1798) by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Robert_Malthus" title="Thomas Robert Malthus">Thomas Robert Malthus</a>, Darwin noted that population growth would lead to a "struggle for existence" in which favourable variations prevailed as others perished. In each generation, many offspring fail to survive to an age of reproduction because of limited resources. This could explain the diversity of plants and animals from a common ancestry through the working of natural laws in the same way for all types of organism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sober09_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sober09-41">[41]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-42"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-43"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> Darwin developed his theory of "natural selection" from 1838 onwards and was writing up his "big book" on the subject when <a href="/wiki/Alfred_Russel_Wallace" title="Alfred Russel Wallace">Alfred Russel Wallace</a> sent him a version of virtually the same theory in 1858. Their <a href="/wiki/On_the_Tendency_of_Species_to_form_Varieties;_and_on_the_Perpetuation_of_Varieties_and_Species_by_Natural_Means_of_Selection" title="On the Tendency of Species to form Varieties; and on the Perpetuation of Varieties and Species by Natural Means of Selection">separate papers</a> were presented together at an 1858 meeting of the <a href="/wiki/Linnean_Society_of_London" title="Linnean Society of London">Linnean Society of London</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-45"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> At the end of 1859, Darwin's publication of his "abstract" as <i>On the Origin of Species</i> explained natural selection in detail and in a way that led to an increasingly wide acceptance of <a href="/wiki/Darwinism" title="Darwinism">Darwin's concepts of evolution</a> at the expense of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Alternatives_to_evolution_by_natural_selection" title="Alternatives to evolution by natural selection">alternative theories</a>. <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Henry_Huxley" title="Thomas Henry Huxley">Thomas Henry Huxley</a> applied Darwin's ideas to humans, using <a href="/wiki/Paleontology" title="Paleontology">paleontology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Comparative_anatomy" title="Comparative anatomy">comparative anatomy</a> to provide strong evidence that humans and <a href="/wiki/Ape" title="Ape">apes</a> shared a common ancestry. Some were disturbed by this since it implied that humans did not have a special place in the <a href="/wiki/Universe" title="Universe">universe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-46"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pangenesis_and_heredity">Pangenesis and heredity</span></h3>
<p>The mechanisms of reproductive heritability and the origin of new traits remained a mystery. Towards this end, Darwin developed his provisional theory of <a href="/wiki/Pangenesis" title="Pangenesis">pangenesis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Liu09_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-Liu09-47">[47]</a></sup> In 1865, <a href="/wiki/Gregor_Mendel" title="Gregor Mendel">Gregor Mendel</a> reported that traits were inherited in a predictable manner through the <a href="/wiki/Mendelian_inheritance#Law_of_Independent_Assortment" title="Mendelian inheritance">independent assortment</a> and segregation of elements (later known as genes). Mendel's laws of inheritance eventually supplanted most of Darwin's pangenesis theory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Weiling_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-Weiling-48">[48]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/August_Weismann" title="August Weismann">August Weismann</a> made the important distinction between <a href="/wiki/Germ_cell" title="Germ cell">germ cells</a> that give rise to <a href="/wiki/Gamete" title="Gamete">gametes</a> (such as <a href="/wiki/Sperm" title="Sperm">sperm</a> and <a href="/wiki/Egg_cell" title="Egg cell">egg cells</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Somatic_cell" title="Somatic cell">somatic cells</a> of the body, demonstrating that heredity passes through the germ line only. <a href="/wiki/Hugo_de_Vries" title="Hugo de Vries">Hugo de Vries</a> connected Darwin's pangenesis theory to Weismann's germ/soma cell distinction and proposed that Darwin's pangenes were concentrated in the <a href="/wiki/Cell_nucleus" title="Cell nucleus">cell nucleus</a> and when expressed they could move into the <a href="/wiki/Cytoplasm" title="Cytoplasm">cytoplasm</a> to change the <a href="/wiki/Cell_(biology)" title="Cell (biology)">cell</a>'s structure. De Vries was also one of the researchers who made Mendel's work well known, believing that Mendelian traits corresponded to the transfer of heritable variations along the germline.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wright84_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wright84-49">[49]</a></sup> To explain how new variants originate, de Vries developed <a href="/wiki/Mutationism" title="Mutationism">a mutation theory</a> that led to a temporary rift between those who accepted Darwinian evolution and biometricians who allied with de Vries.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-50"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-51"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> In the 1930s, pioneers in the field of <a href="/wiki/Population_genetics" title="Population genetics">population genetics</a>, such as <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Fisher" title="Ronald Fisher">Ronald Fisher</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sewall_Wright" title="Sewall Wright">Sewall Wright</a> and <a href="/wiki/J._B._S._Haldane" title="J. B. S. Haldane">J. B. S. Haldane</a> set the foundations of evolution onto a robust statistical philosophy. The false contradiction between Darwin's theory, genetic mutations, and <a href="/wiki/Mendelian_inheritance" title="Mendelian inheritance">Mendelian inheritance</a> was thus reconciled.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowler1989307–318_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowler1989307–318-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="The_.27modern_synthesis.27"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="The_'modern_synthesis'">The 'modern synthesis'</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Modern_synthesis_(20th_century)" title="Modern synthesis (20th century)">Modern synthesis (20th century)</a></div>
<p>In the 1920s and 1930s, the so-called modern synthesis connected natural selection and population genetics, based on Mendelian inheritance, into a unified theory that applied generally to any branch of biology. The modern synthesis explained patterns observed across species in populations, through <a href="/wiki/Transitional_fossil" title="Transitional fossil">fossil transitions</a> in palaeontology.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowler1989307–318_52-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowler1989307–318-52">[52]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Further_syntheses">Further syntheses</span></h3>
<p>Since then, the modern synthesis has been further extended in the light of numerous discoveries, to explain biological phenomena across the full and integrative scale of the <a href="/wiki/Biological_organisation" title="Biological organisation">biological hierarchy</a>, from genes to populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevinson2019_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevinson2019-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>The publication of the structure of <a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> by <a href="/wiki/James_Watson" title="James Watson">James Watson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francis_Crick" title="Francis Crick">Francis Crick</a> with contribution of <a href="/wiki/Rosalind_Franklin" title="Rosalind Franklin">Rosalind Franklin</a> in 1953 demonstrated a physical mechanism for inheritance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Watson53_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-Watson53-54">[54]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Molecular_biology" title="Molecular biology">Molecular biology</a> improved understanding of the relationship between <a href="/wiki/Genotype" title="Genotype">genotype</a> and <a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">phenotype</a>. Advances were also made in phylogenetic <a href="/wiki/Systematics" title="Systematics">systematics</a>, mapping the transition of traits into a comparative and testable framework through the publication and use of <a href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree" title="Phylogenetic tree">evolutionary trees</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hennig99_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hennig99-55">[55]</a></sup> In 1973, evolutionary biologist <a href="/wiki/Theodosius_Dobzhansky" title="Theodosius Dobzhansky">Theodosius Dobzhansky</a> penned that "<a href="/wiki/Nothing_in_Biology_Makes_Sense_Except_in_the_Light_of_Evolution" title="Nothing in Biology Makes Sense Except in the Light of Evolution">nothing in biology makes sense except in the light of evolution</a>," because it has brought to light the relations of what first seemed disjointed facts in natural history into a coherent <a href="/wiki/Explanation" title="Explanation">explanatory</a> body of knowledge that describes and predicts many observable facts about life on this planet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dobzhansky73_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dobzhansky73-56">[56]</a></sup>
</p><p>One extension, known as <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_developmental_biology" title="Evolutionary developmental biology">evolutionary developmental biology</a> and informally called "evo-devo," emphasises how changes between generations (evolution) acts on patterns of change within individual organisms (<a href="/wiki/Developmental_biology" title="Developmental biology">development</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kutschera_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kutschera-57">[57]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Avise10_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-Avise10-58">[58]</a></sup> Since the beginning of the 21st century and in light of discoveries made in recent decades, some biologists have argued for an <a href="/wiki/Extended_evolutionary_synthesis" title="Extended evolutionary synthesis">extended evolutionary synthesis</a>, which would account for the effects of non-genetic inheritance modes, such as <a href="/wiki/Epigenetics" title="Epigenetics">epigenetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maternal_effect" title="Maternal effect">parental effects</a>, ecological inheritance and <a href="/wiki/Dual_inheritance_theory" title="Dual inheritance theory">cultural inheritance</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Evolvability" title="Evolvability">evolvability</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-beyonddna_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-beyonddna-59">[59]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-eesbook_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-eesbook-60">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Heredity">Heredity</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Introduction_to_genetics" title="Introduction to genetics">Introduction to genetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genetics" title="Genetics">Genetics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Heredity" title="Heredity">Heredity</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Reaction_norm" title="Reaction norm">Reaction norm</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:150px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:ADN_static.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="285" data-file-width="148" decoding="async" height="285" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c2/ADN_static.png" width="148"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:ADN_static.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/DNA" title="DNA">DNA</a> structure. <a href="/wiki/Nucleobase" title="Nucleobase">Bases</a> are in the centre, surrounded by phosphate–sugar chains in a <a href="/wiki/Nucleic_acid_double_helix" title="Nucleic acid double helix">double helix</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Evolution in organisms occurs through changes in heritable traits—the inherited characteristics of an organism. In humans, for example, <a href="/wiki/Eye_color" title="Eye color">eye colour</a> is an inherited characteristic and an individual might inherit the "brown-eye trait" from one of their parents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> Inherited traits are controlled by genes and the complete set of genes within an organism's <a href="/wiki/Genome" title="Genome">genome</a> (genetic material) is called its genotype.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pearson_2006_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-Pearson_2006-62">[62]</a></sup>
</p><p>The complete set of observable traits that make up the structure and behaviour of an organism is called its phenotype. These traits come from the interaction of its genotype with the environment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-63"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> As a result, many aspects of an organism's phenotype are not inherited. For example, <a href="/wiki/Sun_tanning" title="Sun tanning">suntanned</a> skin comes from the interaction between a person's genotype and sunlight; thus, suntans are not passed on to people's children. However, some people tan more easily than others, due to differences in genotypic variation; a striking example are people with the inherited trait of <a href="/wiki/Albinism" title="Albinism">albinism</a>, who do not tan at all and are very sensitive to <a href="/wiki/Sunburn" title="Sunburn">sunburn</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-64"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>Heritable traits are passed from one generation to the next via DNA, a <a href="/wiki/Molecule" title="Molecule">molecule</a> that encodes genetic information.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Pearson_2006_62-1"><a href="#cite_note-Pearson_2006-62">[62]</a></sup> DNA is a long <a href="/wiki/Biopolymer" title="Biopolymer">biopolymer</a> composed of four types of bases. The sequence of bases along a particular DNA molecule specify the genetic information, in a manner similar to a sequence of letters spelling out a sentence. Before a cell divides, the DNA is copied, so that each of the resulting two cells will inherit the DNA sequence. Portions of a DNA molecule that specify a single functional unit are called genes; different genes have different sequences of bases. Within cells, the long strands of DNA form condensed structures called <a href="/wiki/Chromosome" title="Chromosome">chromosomes</a>. The specific location of a DNA sequence within a chromosome is known as a <a href="/wiki/Locus_(genetics)" title="Locus (genetics)">locus</a>. If the DNA sequence at a locus varies between individuals, the different forms of this sequence are called alleles. DNA sequences can change through mutations, producing new alleles. If a mutation occurs within a gene, the new allele may affect the trait that the gene controls, altering the phenotype of the organism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma_2005_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma_2005-65">[65]</a></sup> However, while this simple correspondence between an allele and a trait works in some cases, most traits are more complex and are controlled by <a href="/wiki/Quantitative_trait_locus" title="Quantitative trait locus">quantitative trait loci</a> (multiple interacting genes).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lin_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lin-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>Recent findings have confirmed important examples of heritable changes that cannot be explained by changes to the sequence of <a href="/wiki/Nucleotide" title="Nucleotide">nucleotides</a> in the DNA. These phenomena are classed as <a href="/wiki/Epigenetics" title="Epigenetics">epigenetic</a> inheritance systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jablonka09_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jablonka09-68">[68]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/DNA_methylation" title="DNA methylation">DNA methylation</a> marking <a href="/wiki/Chromatin" title="Chromatin">chromatin</a>, self-sustaining metabolic loops, gene silencing by <a href="/wiki/RNA_interference" title="RNA interference">RNA interference</a> and the three-dimensional <a href="/wiki/Protein_structure" title="Protein structure">conformation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Protein" title="Protein">proteins</a> (such as <a href="/wiki/Prion" title="Prion">prions</a>) are areas where epigenetic inheritance systems have been discovered at the organismic level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bossdorf10_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bossdorf10-69">[69]</a></sup> Developmental biologists suggest that complex interactions in <a href="/wiki/Gene_regulatory_network" title="Gene regulatory network">genetic networks</a> and communication among cells can lead to heritable variations that may underlay some of the mechanics in <a href="/wiki/Developmental_plasticity" title="Developmental plasticity">developmental plasticity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Canalisation_(genetics)" title="Canalisation (genetics)">canalisation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jablonka02_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jablonka02-70">[70]</a></sup> Heritability may also occur at even larger scales. For example, ecological inheritance through the process of <a href="/wiki/Niche_construction" title="Niche construction">niche construction</a> is defined by the regular and repeated activities of organisms in their environment. This generates a legacy of effects that modify and feed back into the selection regime of subsequent generations. Descendants inherit genes plus environmental characteristics generated by the ecological actions of ancestors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laland06_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-Laland06-71">[71]</a></sup> Other examples of heritability in evolution that are not under the direct control of genes include the inheritance of <a href="/wiki/Dual_inheritance_theory" title="Dual inheritance theory">cultural traits</a> and <a href="/wiki/Symbiogenesis" title="Symbiogenesis">symbiogenesis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapman98_72-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chapman98-72">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wilson07_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wilson07-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sources_of_variation">Sources of variation</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Genetic_variation" title="Genetic variation">Genetic variation</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Genetic_diversity" title="Genetic diversity">Genetic diversity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Population_genetics" title="Population genetics">Population genetics</a></div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:204px;max-width:204px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Biston.betularia.7200.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1662" data-file-width="2798" decoding="async" height="119" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Biston.betularia.7200.jpg/200px-Biston.betularia.7200.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Biston.betularia.7200.jpg/300px-Biston.betularia.7200.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Biston.betularia.7200.jpg/400px-Biston.betularia.7200.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">White <a href="/wiki/Peppered_moth" title="Peppered moth">peppered moth</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:202px;max-width:202px"><div class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1366" data-file-width="2816" decoding="async" height="97" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg/200px-Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg/300px-Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg/400px-Biston.betularia.f.carbonaria.7209.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">Black morph in <a href="/wiki/Peppered_moth_evolution" title="Peppered moth evolution">peppered moth evolution</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Evolution can occur if there is <a href="/wiki/Genetic_variation" title="Genetic variation">genetic variation</a> within a population. Variation comes from mutations in the genome, reshuffling of genes through <a href="/wiki/Sexual_reproduction" title="Sexual reproduction">sexual reproduction</a> and migration between populations (<a href="/wiki/Gene_flow" title="Gene flow">gene flow</a>). Despite the constant introduction of new variation through mutation and gene flow, most of the genome of a species is identical in all individuals of that species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> However, even relatively small differences in genotype can lead to dramatic differences in phenotype: for example, chimpanzees and humans differ in only about 5% of their genomes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-75"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup>
</p><p>An individual organism's phenotype results from both its genotype and the influence of the environment it has lived in. A substantial part of the phenotypic variation in a population is caused by genotypic variation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lin_67-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lin-67">[67]</a></sup> The modern evolutionary synthesis defines evolution as the change over time in this genetic variation. The frequency of one particular allele will become more or less prevalent relative to other forms of that gene. Variation disappears when a new allele reaches the point of <a href="/wiki/Fixation_(population_genetics)" title="Fixation (population genetics)">fixation</a>—when it either disappears from the population or replaces the ancestral allele entirely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Amos_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-Amos-76">[76]</a></sup>
</p><p>Before the discovery of Mendelian genetics, one common hypothesis was <a href="/wiki/Blending_inheritance" title="Blending inheritance">blending inheritance</a>. But with blending inheritance, genetic variation would be rapidly lost, making evolution by natural selection implausible. The <a href="/wiki/Hardy%E2%80%93Weinberg_principle" title="Hardy–Weinberg principle">Hardy–Weinberg principle</a> provides the solution to how variation is maintained in a population with Mendelian inheritance. The frequencies of alleles (variations in a gene) will remain constant in the absence of selection, mutation, migration and genetic drift.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ewens_W.J._2004_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ewens_W.J._2004-77">[77]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mutation">Mutation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Mutation" title="Mutation">Mutation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gene-duplication.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="354" data-file-width="130" decoding="async" height="463" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Gene-duplication.svg/170px-Gene-duplication.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Gene-duplication.svg/255px-Gene-duplication.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Gene-duplication.svg/340px-Gene-duplication.svg.png 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gene-duplication.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Duplication of part of a <a href="/wiki/Chromosome" title="Chromosome">chromosome</a></div></div></div>
<p>Mutations are changes in the DNA sequence of a cell's genome and are the ultimate source of genetic variation in all organisms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma2017c_3-1"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma2017c-3">[3]</a></sup> When mutations occur, they may alter the <a href="/wiki/Gene_product" title="Gene product">product of a gene</a>, or prevent the gene from functioning, or have no effect. Based on studies in the fly <i><a href="/wiki/Drosophila_melanogaster" title="Drosophila melanogaster">Drosophila melanogaster</a></i>, it has been suggested that if a mutation changes a protein produced by a gene, this will probably be harmful, with about 70% of these mutations having damaging effects, and the remainder being either neutral or weakly beneficial.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>Mutations can involve large sections of a chromosome becoming <a href="/wiki/Gene_duplication" title="Gene duplication">duplicated</a> (usually by <a href="/wiki/Genetic_recombination" title="Genetic recombination">genetic recombination</a>), which can introduce extra copies of a gene into a genome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Extra copies of genes are a major source of the raw material needed for new genes to evolve.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> This is important because most new genes evolve within <a href="/wiki/Gene_family" title="Gene family">gene families</a> from pre-existing genes that share common ancestors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> For example, the human <a href="/wiki/Eye" title="Eye">eye</a> uses four genes to make structures that sense light: three for <a href="/wiki/Cone_cell" title="Cone cell">colour vision</a> and one for <a href="/wiki/Rod_cell" title="Rod cell">night vision</a>; all four are descended from a single ancestral gene.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup>
</p><p>New genes can be generated from an ancestral gene when a duplicate copy mutates and acquires a new function. This process is easier once a gene has been duplicated because it increases the <a href="/wiki/Gene_redundancy" title="Gene redundancy">redundancy</a> of the system; one gene in the pair can acquire a new function while the other copy continues to perform its original function.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-83"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-84"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Other types of mutations can even generate entirely new genes from previously noncoding DNA, a phenomenon termed <a href="/wiki/De_novo_gene_birth" title="De novo gene birth">de novo gene birth</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-86"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>The generation of new genes can also involve small parts of several genes being duplicated, with these fragments then recombining to form new combinations with new functions (<a href="/wiki/Exon_shuffling" title="Exon shuffling">exon shuffling</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-87"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> When new genes are assembled from shuffling pre-existing parts, <a href="/wiki/Protein_domain" title="Protein domain">domains</a> act as modules with simple independent functions, which can be mixed together to produce new combinations with new and complex functions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-89"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> For example, <a href="/wiki/Polyketide_synthase" title="Polyketide synthase">polyketide synthases</a> are large <a href="/wiki/Enzyme" title="Enzyme">enzymes</a> that make <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antibiotics" title="Antibiotics">antibiotics</a>; they contain up to one hundred independent domains that each catalyse one step in the overall process, like a step in an assembly line.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>One example of mutation is <a href="/wiki/Wild_boar" title="Wild boar">wild boar</a> piglets. They are camouflage colored and show a characteristic pattern of dark and light longitudinal stripes. However, mutations in <i><a href="/wiki/Melanocortin_1_receptor" title="Melanocortin 1 receptor">melanocortin 1 receptor</a></i> (<i>MC1R</i>) disrupt the pattern. The majority of pig breeds carry <i>MC1R</i> mutations disrupting wild-type color and different mutations causing dominant black color of the pigs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-91"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sex_and_recombination">Sex and recombination</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Sexual_reproduction" title="Sexual reproduction">Sexual reproduction</a>, <a href="/wiki/Genetic_recombination" title="Genetic recombination">Genetic recombination</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_sexual_reproduction" title="Evolution of sexual reproduction">Evolution of sexual reproduction</a></div>
<p>In <a href="/wiki/Asexual_reproduction" title="Asexual reproduction">asexual</a> organisms, genes are inherited together, or <i>linked</i>, as they cannot mix with genes of other organisms during reproduction. In contrast, the offspring of <a href="/wiki/Sex" title="Sex">sexual</a> organisms contain random mixtures of their parents' chromosomes that are produced through independent assortment. In a related process called <a href="/wiki/Homologous_recombination" title="Homologous recombination">homologous recombination</a>, sexual organisms exchange DNA between two matching chromosomes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-92"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> Recombination and reassortment do not alter allele frequencies, but instead change which alleles are associated with each other, producing offspring with new combinations of alleles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Agrawal_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-Agrawal-93">[93]</a></sup> Sex usually increases genetic variation and may increase the rate of evolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-95"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Evolsex-dia1a.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="389" data-file-width="700" decoding="async" height="139" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Evolsex-dia1a.png/250px-Evolsex-dia1a.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Evolsex-dia1a.png/375px-Evolsex-dia1a.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Evolsex-dia1a.png/500px-Evolsex-dia1a.png 2x" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Evolsex-dia1a.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>This diagram illustrates the <i>twofold cost of sex</i>. If each individual were to contribute to the same number of offspring (two), <i>(a)</i> the <a href="/wiki/Sex" title="Sex">sexual</a> population remains the same size each generation, where the <i>(b)</i> <a href="/wiki/Asexual_reproduction" title="Asexual reproduction">Asexual reproduction</a> population doubles in size each generation.</div></div></div>
<p>The two-fold cost of sex was first described by <a href="/wiki/John_Maynard_Smith" title="John Maynard Smith">John Maynard Smith</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-maynard_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-maynard-96">[96]</a></sup> The first cost is that in sexually dimorphic species only one of the two sexes can bear young. This cost does not apply to hermaphroditic species, like most plants and many <a href="/wiki/Invertebrate" title="Invertebrate">invertebrates</a>. The second cost is that any individual who reproduces sexually can only pass on 50% of its genes to any individual offspring, with even less passed on as each new generation passes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ridley_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-ridley-97">[97]</a></sup> Yet sexual reproduction is the more common means of reproduction among eukaryotes and multicellular organisms. The <a href="/wiki/Red_Queen_hypothesis" title="Red Queen hypothesis">Red Queen hypothesis</a> has been used to explain the significance of sexual reproduction as a means to enable continual evolution and adaptation in response to <a href="/wiki/Coevolution" title="Coevolution">coevolution</a> with other species in an ever-changing environment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ridley_97-1"><a href="#cite_note-ridley-97">[97]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-red_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-red-98">[98]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-parasite_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-parasite-99">[99]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Birdsell_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-Birdsell-100">[100]</a></sup>  Another hypothesis is that <a href="/wiki/Sexual_reproduction" title="Sexual reproduction">sexual reproduction</a> is primarily an adaptation for promoting accurate <a href="/wiki/Homologous_recombination" title="Homologous recombination">recombinational repair of damage</a> in germline DNA, and that increased diversity is a byproduct of this process that may sometimes be adaptively beneficial.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gene_flow">Gene flow</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Gene_flow" title="Gene flow">Gene flow</a></div>
<p>Gene flow is the exchange of genes between populations and between species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morjan_C,_Rieseberg_L_2004_1341–56_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-Morjan_C,_Rieseberg_L_2004_1341–56-103">[103]</a></sup> It can therefore be a source of variation that is new to a population or to a species. Gene flow can be caused by the movement of individuals between separate populations of organisms, as might be caused by the movement of mice between inland and coastal populations, or the movement of <a href="/wiki/Pollen" title="Pollen">pollen</a> between heavy-metal-tolerant and heavy-metal-sensitive populations of grasses.
</p><p>Gene transfer between species includes the formation of <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">hybrid</a> organisms and <a href="/wiki/Horizontal_gene_transfer" title="Horizontal gene transfer">horizontal gene transfer</a>. Horizontal gene transfer is the transfer of genetic material from one organism to another organism that is not its offspring; this is most common among <a href="/wiki/Bacteria" title="Bacteria">bacteria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-104"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup> In medicine, this contributes to the spread of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antibiotic_resistance" title="Antibiotic resistance">antibiotic resistance</a>, as when one bacteria acquires resistance genes it can rapidly transfer them to other species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-GeneticEvolution_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-GeneticEvolution-105">[105]</a></sup> Horizontal transfer of genes from bacteria to eukaryotes such as the yeast <i><a href="/wiki/Saccharomyces_cerevisiae" title="Saccharomyces cerevisiae">Saccharomyces cerevisiae</a></i> and the adzuki bean weevil <i><a href="/wiki/Callosobruchus_chinensis" title="Callosobruchus chinensis">Callosobruchus chinensis</a></i> has occurred.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-106"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-107"><a href="#cite_note-107">[107]</a></sup> An example of larger-scale transfers are the eukaryotic <a href="/wiki/Bdelloidea" title="Bdelloidea">bdelloid rotifers</a>, which have received a range of genes from bacteria, <a href="/wiki/Fungus" title="Fungus">fungi</a> and plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-108"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Virus" title="Virus">Viruses</a> can also carry DNA between organisms, allowing transfer of genes even across <a href="/wiki/Domain_(biology)" title="Domain (biology)">biological domains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p><p>Large-scale gene transfer has also occurred between the ancestors of <a href="/wiki/Eukaryote" title="Eukaryote">eukaryotic cells</a> and bacteria, during the acquisition of <a href="/wiki/Chloroplast" title="Chloroplast">chloroplasts</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mitochondrion" title="Mitochondrion">mitochondria</a>. It is possible that eukaryotes themselves originated from horizontal gene transfers between bacteria and <a href="/wiki/Archaea" title="Archaea">archaea</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolutionary_processes">Evolutionary processes</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="331" decoding="async" height="272" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg/300px-Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg/450px-Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f3/Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg/600px-Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Mutation_and_selection_diagram.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Mutation" title="Mutation">Mutation</a> followed by natural selection results in a population with darker colouration.</div></div></div>
<p>From a <a href="/wiki/Neo-Darwinism" title="Neo-Darwinism">neo-Darwinian</a> perspective, evolution occurs when there are changes in the frequencies of alleles within a population of interbreeding organisms,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ewens_W.J._2004_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ewens_W.J._2004-77">[77]</a></sup> for example, the allele for black colour in a population of moths becoming more common. Mechanisms that can lead to changes in allele frequencies include natural selection, genetic drift, gene flow and mutation bias.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Natural_selection">Natural selection</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Natural_selection" title="Natural selection">Natural selection</a></div>
<p>Evolution by natural selection is the process by which traits that enhance survival and reproduction become more common in successive generations of a population. It embodies three principles:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lewontin70_8-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lewontin70-8">[8]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li>Variation exists within populations of organisms with respect to morphology, physiology and behaviour (phenotypic variation).</li>
<li>Different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction (differential fitness).</li>
<li>These traits can be passed from generation to generation (heritability of fitness).</li></ul>
<p>More offspring are produced than can possibly survive, and these conditions produce competition between organisms for survival and reproduction. Consequently, organisms with traits that give them an advantage over their competitors are more likely to pass on their traits to the next generation than those with traits that do not confer an advantage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hurst_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hurst-111">[111]</a></sup> This <a href="/wiki/Teleonomy" title="Teleonomy">teleonomy</a> is the quality whereby the process of natural selection creates and preserves traits that are <a href="/wiki/Teleology_in_biology" title="Teleology in biology">seemingly fitted</a> for the <a href="/wiki/Function_(biology)" title="Function (biology)">functional</a> roles they perform.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> Consequences of selection include <a href="/wiki/Assortative_mating" title="Assortative mating">nonrandom mating</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[113]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Genetic_hitchhiking" title="Genetic hitchhiking">genetic hitchhiking</a>.
</p><p>The central concept of natural selection is the <a href="/wiki/Fitness_(biology)" title="Fitness (biology)">evolutionary fitness</a> of an organism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Orr_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-Orr-114">[114]</a></sup> Fitness is measured by an organism's ability to survive and reproduce, which determines the size of its genetic contribution to the next generation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Orr_114-1"><a href="#cite_note-Orr-114">[114]</a></sup> However, fitness is not the same as the total number of offspring: instead fitness is indicated by the proportion of subsequent generations that carry an organism's genes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haldane_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haldane-115">[115]</a></sup> For example, if an organism could survive well and reproduce rapidly, but its offspring were all too small and weak to survive, this organism would make little genetic contribution to future generations and would thus have low fitness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Orr_114-2"><a href="#cite_note-Orr-114">[114]</a></sup>
</p><p>If an allele increases fitness more than the other alleles of that gene, then with each generation this allele will become more common within the population. These traits are said to be "selected <i>for</i>." Examples of traits that can increase fitness are enhanced survival and increased <a href="/wiki/Fecundity" title="Fecundity">fecundity</a>. Conversely, the lower fitness caused by having a less beneficial or deleterious allele results in this allele becoming rarer—they are "selected <i>against</i>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lande_116-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lande-116">[116]</a></sup> Importantly, the fitness of an allele is not a fixed characteristic; if the environment changes, previously neutral or harmful traits may become beneficial and previously beneficial traits become harmful.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma_2005_65-1"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma_2005-65">[65]</a></sup> However, even if the direction of selection does reverse in this way, traits that were lost in the past may not re-evolve in an identical form (see <a href="/wiki/Dollo%27s_law_of_irreversibility" title="Dollo's law of irreversibility">Dollo's law</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> However, a re-activation of dormant genes, as long as they have not been eliminated from the genome and were only suppressed perhaps for hundreds of generations, can lead to the re-occurrence of traits thought to be lost like hindlegs in <a href="/wiki/Dolphin" title="Dolphin">dolphins</a>, teeth in <a href="/wiki/Chicken" title="Chicken">chickens</a>, wings in wingless stick <a href="/wiki/Insect" title="Insect">insects</a>, tails and additional nipples in humans etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-119"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> "Throwbacks" such as these are known as <a href="/wiki/Atavism" title="Atavism">atavisms</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:322px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Genetic_Distribution.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="510" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="319" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Genetic_Distribution.svg/320px-Genetic_Distribution.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Genetic_Distribution.svg/480px-Genetic_Distribution.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Genetic_Distribution.svg/640px-Genetic_Distribution.svg.png 2x" width="320"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Genetic_Distribution.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>These charts depict the different types of genetic selection. On each graph, the x-axis variable is the type of <a href="/wiki/Phenotypic_trait" title="Phenotypic trait">phenotypic trait</a> and the y-axis variable is the number of organisms. Group A is the original population and Group B is the population after selection.<br/> <b>·</b> Graph 1 shows <a href="/wiki/Directional_selection" title="Directional selection">directional selection</a>, in which a single extreme <a href="/wiki/Phenotype" title="Phenotype">phenotype</a> is favoured.<br/> <b>·</b> Graph 2 depicts <a href="/wiki/Stabilizing_selection" title="Stabilizing selection">stabilizing selection</a>, where the intermediate phenotype is favoured over the extreme traits.<br/> <b>·</b> Graph 3 shows <a href="/wiki/Disruptive_selection" title="Disruptive selection">disruptive selection</a>, in which the extreme phenotypes are favoured over the intermediate.</div></div></div>
<p>Natural selection within a population for a trait that can vary across a range of values, such as height, can be categorised into three different types. The first is <a href="/wiki/Directional_selection" title="Directional selection">directional selection</a>, which is a shift in the average value of a trait over time—for example, organisms slowly getting taller.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-120"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Secondly, <a href="/wiki/Disruptive_selection" title="Disruptive selection">disruptive selection</a> is selection for extreme trait values and often results in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bimodal_distribution" title="Bimodal distribution">two different values</a> becoming most common, with selection against the average value. This would be when either short or tall organisms had an advantage, but not those of medium height. Finally, in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Stabilising_selection" title="Stabilising selection">stabilising selection</a> there is selection against extreme trait values on both ends, which causes a decrease in <a href="/wiki/Variance" title="Variance">variance</a> around the average value and less diversity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hurst_111-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hurst-111">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> This would, for example, cause organisms to eventually have a similar height.
</p><p>Natural selection most generally makes nature the measure against which individuals and individual traits, are more or less likely to survive. "Nature" in this sense refers to an <a href="/wiki/Ecosystem" title="Ecosystem">ecosystem</a>, that is, a system in which organisms interact with every other element, <a href="/wiki/Abiotic_component" title="Abiotic component">physical</a> as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Biotic_component" title="Biotic component">biological</a>, in their local environment. <a href="/wiki/Eugene_Odum" title="Eugene Odum">Eugene Odum</a>, a founder of <a href="/wiki/Ecology" title="Ecology">ecology</a>, defined an ecosystem as: "Any unit that includes all of the organisms...in a given area interacting with the physical environment so that a flow of energy leads to clearly defined trophic structure, biotic diversity, and material cycles (i.e., exchange of materials between living and nonliving parts) within the system...."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Odum1971_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-Odum1971-122">[122]</a></sup> Each population within an ecosystem occupies a distinct <a href="/wiki/Ecological_niche" title="Ecological niche">niche</a>, or position, with distinct relationships to other parts of the system. These relationships involve the life history of the organism, its position in the <a href="/wiki/Food_chain" title="Food chain">food chain</a> and its geographic range. This broad understanding of nature enables scientists to delineate specific forces which, together, comprise natural selection.
</p><p>Natural selection can act at <a href="/wiki/Unit_of_selection" title="Unit of selection">different levels of organisation</a>, such as genes, cells, individual organisms, groups of organisms and species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Okasha07_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-Okasha07-123">[123]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gould_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gould-124">[124]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mayr1997_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mayr1997-125">[125]</a></sup> Selection can act at multiple levels simultaneously.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-126"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> An example of selection occurring below the level of the individual organism are genes called <a href="/wiki/Transposable_element" title="Transposable element">transposons</a>, which can replicate and spread throughout a genome.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-127"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> Selection at a level above the individual, such as <a href="/wiki/Group_selection" title="Group selection">group selection</a>, may allow the evolution of cooperation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-128"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Genetic_hitchhiking">Genetic hitchhiking</span></h4>
