<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Genetic_hitchhiking" title="Genetic hitchhiking">Genetic hitchhiking</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hill%E2%80%93Robertson_effect" title="Hill–Robertson effect">Hill–Robertson effect</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Selective_sweep" title="Selective sweep">Selective sweep</a></div>
<p>Recombination allows alleles on the same strand of DNA to become separated. However, the rate of recombination is low (approximately two events per chromosome per generation). As a result, genes close together on a chromosome may not always be shuffled away from each other and genes that are close together tend to be inherited together, a phenomenon known as <a href="/wiki/Genetic_linkage" title="Genetic linkage">linkage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-129"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup> This tendency is measured by finding how often two alleles occur together on a single chromosome compared to <a href="/wiki/Independence_(probability_theory)" title="Independence (probability theory)">expectations</a>, which is called their <a href="/wiki/Linkage_disequilibrium" title="Linkage disequilibrium">linkage disequilibrium</a>. A set of alleles that is usually inherited in a group is called a <a href="/wiki/Haplotype" title="Haplotype">haplotype</a>. This can be important when one allele in a particular haplotype is strongly beneficial: natural selection can drive a <a href="/wiki/Selective_sweep" title="Selective sweep">selective sweep</a> that will also cause the other alleles in the haplotype to become more common in the population; this effect is called genetic hitchhiking or genetic draft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> Genetic draft caused by the fact that some neutral genes are genetically linked to others that are under selection can be partially captured by an appropriate effective population size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gillespie_2001_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-gillespie_2001-131">[131]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Sexual_selection">Sexual selection</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Sexual_selection" title="Sexual selection">Sexual selection</a></div>
<p>A special case of natural selection is sexual selection, which is selection for any trait that increases mating success by increasing the attractiveness of an organism to potential mates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup> Traits that evolved through sexual selection are particularly prominent among males of several animal species. Although sexually favoured, traits such as cumbersome antlers, mating calls, large body size and bright colours often attract predation, which compromises the survival of individual males.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Balancing_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-Balancing-134">[134]</a></sup> This survival disadvantage is balanced by higher reproductive success in males that show these <a href="/wiki/Handicap_principle" title="Handicap principle">hard-to-fake</a>, sexually selected traits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Genetic_drift">Genetic drift</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Genetic_drift" title="Genetic drift">Genetic drift</a> and <a href="/wiki/Effective_population_size" title="Effective population size">Effective population size</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Allele-frequency.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="333" decoding="async" height="238" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Allele-frequency.png/220px-Allele-frequency.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/Allele-frequency.png/330px-Allele-frequency.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/46/Allele-frequency.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Allele-frequency.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Simulation of genetic drift of 20 unlinked alleles in populations of 10 (top) and 100 (bottom). Drift to <a href="/wiki/Fixation_(population_genetics)" title="Fixation (population genetics)">fixation</a> is more rapid in the smaller population.</div></div></div>
<p>Genetic drift is the random fluctuations of <a href="/wiki/Allele_frequency" title="Allele frequency">allele frequencies</a> within a population from one generation to the next.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Futuyma2017b_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-Futuyma2017b-136">[136]</a></sup> When selective forces are absent or relatively weak, allele frequencies are equally likely to <i>drift</i> upward or downward at each successive generation because the alleles are subject to <a href="/wiki/Sampling_error" title="Sampling error">sampling error</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Masel_2011_137-0"><a href="#cite_note-Masel_2011-137">[137]</a></sup> This drift halts when an allele eventually becomes fixed, either by disappearing from the population or replacing the other alleles entirely. Genetic drift may therefore eliminate some alleles from a population due to chance alone. Even in the absence of selective forces, genetic drift can cause two separate populations that began with the same genetic structure to drift apart into two divergent populations with different sets of alleles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Neutral_theory_of_molecular_evolution" title="Neutral theory of molecular evolution">neutral theory of molecular evolution</a> proposed that most evolutionary changes are the result of the fixation of <a href="/wiki/Neutral_mutation" title="Neutral mutation">neutral mutations</a> by genetic drift.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kimura_M_1991_367–86_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-Kimura_M_1991_367–86-139">[139]</a></sup> Hence, in this model, most genetic changes in a population are the result of constant mutation pressure and genetic drift.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> This form of the neutral theory is now largely abandoned, since it does not seem to fit the genetic variation seen in nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup> However, a more recent and better-supported version of this model is the <a href="/wiki/Nearly_neutral_theory_of_molecular_evolution" title="Nearly neutral theory of molecular evolution">nearly neutral theory</a>, where a mutation that would be effectively neutral in a small population is not necessarily neutral in a large population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hurst_111-2"><a href="#cite_note-Hurst-111">[111]</a></sup> Other alternative theories propose that genetic drift is dwarfed by other stochastic forces in evolution, such as genetic hitchhiking, also known as genetic draft.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Masel_2011_137-1"><a href="#cite_note-Masel_2011-137">[137]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gillespie_2001_131-1"><a href="#cite_note-gillespie_2001-131">[131]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-143"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> Another concept is <a href="/wiki/Constructive_neutral_evolution" title="Constructive neutral evolution">constructive neutral evolution</a> (CNE), which explains that complex systems can emerge and spread into a population through neutral transitions with the principles of excess capacity, presuppression, and ratcheting,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-144"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-145"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> and it has been applied in areas ranging from the origins of the <a href="/wiki/Spliceosome" title="Spliceosome">spliceosome</a> to the complex interdependence of <a href="/wiki/Microbial_consortium" title="Microbial consortium">microbial communities</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-147"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-149"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p><p>The time for a neutral allele to become fixed by genetic drift depends on population size, with fixation occurring more rapidly in smaller populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-150"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> The number of individuals in a population is not critical, but instead a measure known as the effective population size.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Charlesworth_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-Charlesworth-151">[151]</a></sup> The effective population is usually smaller than the total population since it takes into account factors such as the level of inbreeding and the stage of the lifecycle in which the population is the smallest.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Charlesworth_151-1"><a href="#cite_note-Charlesworth-151">[151]</a></sup> The effective population size may not be the same for every gene in the same population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-152"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is usually difficult to measure the relative importance of selection and neutral processes, including drift.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> The comparative importance of adaptive and non-adaptive forces in driving evolutionary change is an area of <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_biology" title="Evolutionary biology">current research</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Gene_flow_2">Gene flow</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Gene_flow" title="Gene flow">Gene flow</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_(biology)" title="Hybrid (biology)">Hybrid (biology)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Horizontal_gene_transfer" title="Horizontal gene transfer">Horizontal gene transfer</a></div>
<p>Gene flow involves the exchange of genes between populations and between species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Morjan_C,_Rieseberg_L_2004_1341–56_103-1"><a href="#cite_note-Morjan_C,_Rieseberg_L_2004_1341–56-103">[103]</a></sup> The presence or absence of gene flow fundamentally changes the course of evolution. Due to the complexity of organisms, any two completely isolated populations will eventually evolve genetic incompatibilities through neutral processes, as in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bateson-Dobzhansky-Muller_Model" title="Bateson-Dobzhansky-Muller Model">Bateson-Dobzhansky-Muller model</a>, even if both populations remain essentially identical in terms of their adaptation to the environment.
</p><p>If genetic differentiation between populations develops, gene flow between populations can introduce traits or alleles which are disadvantageous in the local population and this may lead to organisms within these populations evolving mechanisms that prevent mating with genetically distant populations, eventually resulting in the appearance of new species. Thus, exchange of genetic information between individuals is fundamentally important for the development of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Species_problem#Mayr's_Biological_Species_Concept" title="Species problem"><i>Biological Species Concept</i></a>.
</p><p>During the development of the modern synthesis, Sewall Wright developed his <a href="/wiki/Shifting_balance_theory" title="Shifting balance theory">shifting balance theory</a>, which regarded gene flow between partially isolated populations as an important aspect of adaptive evolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-155"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup> However, recently there has been substantial criticism of the importance of the shifting balance theory.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coyne_1997_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coyne_1997-156">[156]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Mutation_bias">Mutation bias</span></h3>
<p><a href="/wiki/Mutation_bias" title="Mutation bias">Mutation bias</a> is usually conceived as a difference in expected rates for two different kinds of mutation, e.g., transition-transversion bias, GC-AT bias, deletion-insertion bias. This is related to the idea of <a href="/wiki/Developmental_bias" title="Developmental bias">developmental bias</a>.
</p><p>Haldane<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Haldane1927_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-Haldane1927-157">[157]</a></sup> and Fisher<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fisher1930_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fisher1930-158">[158]</a></sup> argued that, because mutation is a weak pressure easily overcome by selection, tendencies of mutation would be ineffectual except under conditions of neutral evolution or extraordinarily high mutation rates. This opposing-pressures argument was long used to dismiss the possibility of internal tendencies in evolution,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YampolskyStoltzfus2001_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-YampolskyStoltzfus2001-159">[159]</a></sup> until the molecular era prompted renewed interest in neutral evolution.
</p><p>Noboru Sueoka<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sueoka1962_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sueoka1962-160">[160]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Freese" title="Ernst Freese">Ernst Freese</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Freese1962_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-Freese1962-161">[161]</a></sup> proposed that systematic biases in mutation might be responsible for systematic differences in genomic GC composition between species. The identification of a GC-biased <i>E. coli</i> mutator strain in 1967,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-CoxYanofsky1967_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-CoxYanofsky1967-162">[162]</a></sup> along with the proposal of the <a href="/wiki/Neutral_theory_of_molecular_evolution" title="Neutral theory of molecular evolution">neutral theory</a>, established the plausibility of mutational explanations for molecular patterns, which are now common in the molecular evolution literature.
</p><p>For instance, mutation biases are frequently invoked in models of codon usage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ShahGilchrist2011_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-ShahGilchrist2011-163">[163]</a></sup> Such models also include effects of selection, following the mutation-selection-drift model,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bulmer1991_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bulmer1991-164">[164]</a></sup> which allows both for mutation biases and differential selection based on effects on translation. Hypotheses of mutation bias have played an important role in the development of thinking about the evolution of genome composition, including isochores.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FryxellZuckerkandl2000_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FryxellZuckerkandl2000-165">[165]</a></sup> Different insertion vs. deletion biases in different <a href="/wiki/Taxon" title="Taxon">taxa</a> can lead to the evolution of different genome sizes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-166"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-167"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup> The hypothesis of Lynch regarding genome size relies on mutational biases toward increase or decrease in genome size.
</p><p>However, mutational hypotheses for the evolution of composition suffered a reduction in scope when it was discovered that (1) GC-biased gene conversion makes an important contribution to composition in diploid organisms such as mammals<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Duret2009_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-Duret2009-168">[168]</a></sup> and (2) bacterial genomes frequently have AT-biased mutation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hershberg2010_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hershberg2010-169">[169]</a></sup>
</p><p>Contemporary thinking about the role of mutation biases reflects a different theory from that of Haldane and Fisher. More recent work<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-YampolskyStoltzfus2001_159-1"><a href="#cite_note-YampolskyStoltzfus2001-159">[159]</a></sup> showed that the original "pressures" theory assumes that evolution is based on standing variation: when evolution depends on the introduction of new alleles, mutational and developmental biases in the introduction can impose biases on evolution <i>without requiring neutral evolution or high mutation rates</i>.
</p><p>Several recent studies report that the mutations implicated in adaptation reflect common mutation biases<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StoltzfusMcCandlish2017_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-StoltzfusMcCandlish2017-170">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Payne2019_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-Payne2019-171">[171]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Storz2019_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-Storz2019-172">[172]</a></sup> though others dispute this interpretation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SvenssonBerger2019_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-SvenssonBerger2019-173">[173]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Outcomes">Outcomes</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;"><video class="thumbimage" controls="" data-durationhint="115" data-mwprovider="wikimediacommons" data-mwtitle="Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm" height="186" id="mwe_player_0" poster="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/330px-seek%3D106-Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.jpg" preload="none" width="330"><source data-bandwidth="245328" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="480" data-shorttitle="VP9 480P" data-title="SD VP9 (480P)" data-transcodekey="480p.vp9.webm" data-width="854" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.480p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="507222" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="720" data-shorttitle="WebM source" data-title="Original WebM file, 1,280 × 720 (507 kbps)" data-width="1280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="1091056" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="480" data-shorttitle="WebM 480P" data-title="SD WebM (480P)" data-transcodekey="480p.webm" data-width="854" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.480p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="1867000" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="720" data-shorttitle="WebM 720P" data-title="HD WebM (720P)" data-transcodekey="720p.webm" data-width="1280" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.720p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="107864" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="120" data-shorttitle="VP9 120P" data-title="Lowest bandwidth VP9 (120P)" data-transcodekey="120p.vp9.webm" data-width="214" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.120p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="211544" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="160" data-shorttitle="WebM 160P" data-title="Low bandwidth WebM (160P)" data-transcodekey="160p.webm" data-width="284" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.160p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="120664" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="180" data-shorttitle="VP9 180P" data-title="Low bandwidth VP9 (180P)" data-transcodekey="180p.vp9.webm" data-width="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.180p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="134792" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="240" data-shorttitle="VP9 240P" data-title="Small VP9 (240P)" data-transcodekey="240p.vp9.webm" data-width="426" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.240p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="313584" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="240" data-shorttitle="WebM 240P" data-title="Small WebM (240P)" data-transcodekey="240p.webm" data-width="426" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.240p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><source data-bandwidth="172096" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="360" data-shorttitle="VP9 360P" data-title="VP9 (360P)" data-transcodekey="360p.vp9.webm" data-width="640" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.360p.vp9.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp9, opus"'/><source data-bandwidth="568976" data-framerate="29.97" data-height="360" data-shorttitle="WebM 360P" data-title="WebM (360P)" data-transcodekey="360p.webm" data-width="640" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/transcoded/7/7a/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm/Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm.360p.webm" type='video/webm; codecs="vp8, vorbis"'/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="English ‪(en)‬" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AKishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm&amp;lang=en&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="en" type="text/vtt"/><track data-dir="ltr" kind="subtitles" label="svenska ‪(sv)‬" src="https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/api.php?action=timedtext&amp;title=File%3AKishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm&amp;lang=sv&amp;trackformat=vtt&amp;origin=%2A" srclang="sv" type="text/vtt"/></video> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kishony_lab-The_Evolution_of_Bacteria_on_a_Mega-Plate.webm" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A visual demonstration of rapid <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antibiotic_resistance" title="Antibiotic resistance">antibiotic resistance</a> evolution by <i>E. coli</i> growing across a plate with increasing concentrations of <a href="/wiki/Trimethoprim" title="Trimethoprim">trimethoprim</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-174"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Evolution influences every aspect of the form and behaviour of organisms. Most prominent are the specific behavioural and physical adaptations that are the outcome of natural selection. These adaptations increase fitness by aiding activities such as finding food, avoiding <a href="/wiki/Predation" title="Predation">predators</a> or attracting mates. Organisms can also respond to selection by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Co-operation_(evolution)" title="Co-operation (evolution)">cooperating</a> with each other, usually by aiding their relatives or engaging in mutually beneficial <a href="/wiki/Symbiosis" title="Symbiosis">symbiosis</a>. In the longer term, evolution produces new species through splitting ancestral populations of organisms into new groups that cannot or will not interbreed.
</p><p>These outcomes of evolution are distinguished based on time scale as <a href="/wiki/Macroevolution" title="Macroevolution">macroevolution</a> versus microevolution. Macroevolution refers to evolution that occurs at or above the level of species, in particular speciation and extinction; whereas microevolution refers to smaller evolutionary changes within a species or population, in particular shifts in <a href="/wiki/Allele_frequency" title="Allele frequency">allele frequency</a> and adaptation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ScottEC_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-ScottEC-175">[175]</a></sup> In general, macroevolution is regarded as the outcome of long periods of microevolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-176"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup> Thus, the distinction between micro- and macroevolution is not a fundamental one—the difference is simply the time involved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-177"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup> However, in macroevolution, the traits of the entire species may be important. For instance, a large amount of variation among individuals allows a species to rapidly adapt to new <a href="/wiki/Habitat" title="Habitat">habitats</a>, lessening the chance of it going extinct, while a wide geographic range increases the chance of speciation, by making it more likely that part of the population will become isolated. In this sense, microevolution and macroevolution might involve selection at different levels—with microevolution acting on genes and organisms, versus macroevolutionary processes such as <a href="/wiki/Unit_of_selection#Species_and_higher_levels" title="Unit of selection">species selection</a> acting on entire species and affecting their rates of speciation and extinction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould2002657–658_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould2002657–658-178">[178]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gould_1994_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gould_1994-179">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jablonski2000_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jablonski2000-180">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>A common misconception is that evolution has goals, long-term plans, or an innate tendency for "progress", as expressed in beliefs such as orthogenesis and evolutionism; realistically however, evolution has no long-term goal and does not necessarily produce greater complexity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sciam_1998_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-sciam_1998-181">[181]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-182"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> Although <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_biological_complexity" title="Evolution of biological complexity">complex species</a> have evolved, they occur as a side effect of the overall number of organisms increasing and simple forms of life still remain more common in the biosphere.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Carroll_2001_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-Carroll_2001-184">[184]</a></sup> For example, the overwhelming majority of species are microscopic <a href="/wiki/Prokaryote" title="Prokaryote">prokaryotes</a>, which form about half the world's <a href="/wiki/Biomass_(ecology)" title="Biomass (ecology)">biomass</a> despite their small size,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> and constitute the vast majority of Earth's biodiversity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schloss_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-Schloss-186">[186]</a></sup> Simple organisms have therefore been the dominant form of life on Earth throughout its history and continue to be the main form of life up to the present day, with complex life only appearing more diverse because it is <a href="/wiki/Sampling_bias" title="Sampling bias">more noticeable</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup> Indeed, the evolution of microorganisms is particularly important to <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_biology" title="Evolutionary biology">modern evolutionary research</a>, since their rapid reproduction allows the study of <a href="/wiki/Experimental_evolution" title="Experimental evolution">experimental evolution</a> and the observation of evolution and adaptation in real time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Buckling_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-Buckling-188">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Adaptation">Adaptation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Adaptation" title="Adaptation">Adaptation</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Homology_vertebrates-en.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="367" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="215" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Homology_vertebrates-en.svg/300px-Homology_vertebrates-en.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Homology_vertebrates-en.svg/450px-Homology_vertebrates-en.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Homology_vertebrates-en.svg/600px-Homology_vertebrates-en.svg.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Homology_vertebrates-en.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Homology_(biology)" title="Homology (biology)">Homologous</a> bones in the limbs of <a href="/wiki/Tetrapod" title="Tetrapod">tetrapods</a>. The bones of these animals have the same basic structure, but have been <a href="/wiki/Adaptation" title="Adaptation">adapted</a> for specific uses.</div></div></div>
<p>Adaptation is the process that makes organisms better suited to their habitat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-190"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-191"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> Also, the term adaptation may refer to a trait that is important for an organism's survival. For example, the adaptation of <a href="/wiki/Horse" title="Horse">horses</a>' teeth to the grinding of grass. By using the term <i>adaptation</i> for the evolutionary process and <i>adaptive trait</i> for the product (the bodily part or function), the two senses of the word may be distinguished. Adaptations are produced by natural selection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-192"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> The following definitions are due to Theodosius Dobzhansky:
</p>
<ol><li><i>Adaptation</i> is the evolutionary process whereby an organism becomes better able to live in its habitat or habitats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-193"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup></li>
<li><i>Adaptedness</i> is the state of being adapted: the degree to which an organism is able to live and reproduce in a given set of habitats.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-194"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup></li>
<li>An <i>adaptive trait</i> is an aspect of the developmental pattern of the organism which enables or enhances the probability of that organism surviving and reproducing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-195"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>Adaptation may cause either the gain of a new feature, or the loss of an ancestral feature. An example that shows both types of change is bacterial adaptation to antibiotic selection, with genetic changes causing antibiotic resistance by both modifying the target of the drug, or increasing the activity of transporters that pump the drug out of the cell.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-196"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup> Other striking examples are the bacteria <i><a href="/wiki/Escherichia_coli" title="Escherichia coli">Escherichia coli</a></i> evolving the ability to use <a href="/wiki/Citric_acid" title="Citric acid">citric acid</a> as a nutrient in a <a href="/wiki/E._coli_long-term_evolution_experiment" title="E. coli long-term evolution experiment">long-term laboratory experiment</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-197"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> <i><a href="/wiki/Flavobacterium" title="Flavobacterium">Flavobacterium</a></i> evolving a novel enzyme that allows these bacteria to grow on the by-products of <a href="/wiki/Nylon" title="Nylon">nylon</a> manufacturing,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-198"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-199"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup> and the soil bacterium <i><a href="/wiki/Sphingobium" title="Sphingobium">Sphingobium</a></i> evolving an entirely new <a href="/wiki/Metabolic_pathway" title="Metabolic pathway">metabolic pathway</a> that degrades the synthetic <a href="/wiki/Pesticide" title="Pesticide">pesticide</a> <a href="/wiki/Pentachlorophenol" title="Pentachlorophenol">pentachlorophenol</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> An interesting but still controversial idea is that some adaptations might increase the ability of organisms to generate genetic diversity and adapt by natural selection (increasing organisms' evolvability).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-202"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources#Bundling_citations" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources"><span title="This claim has too many footnotes for reading to be smooth. (September 2021)">excessive citations</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Whale_skeleton.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="400" data-file-width="1388" decoding="async" height="86" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Whale_skeleton.png/300px-Whale_skeleton.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Whale_skeleton.png/450px-Whale_skeleton.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Whale_skeleton.png/600px-Whale_skeleton.png 2x" width="300"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Whale_skeleton.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Baleen_whale" title="Baleen whale">baleen whale</a> skeleton. Letters <i>a</i> and <i>b</i> label <a href="/wiki/Flipper_(anatomy)" title="Flipper (anatomy)">flipper</a> bones, which were adapted from front <a href="/wiki/Leg" title="Leg">leg</a> bones, while <i>c</i> indicates <a href="/wiki/Vestigiality" title="Vestigiality">vestigial</a> leg bones, both suggesting an adaptation from land to sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transformation445_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-transformation445-207">[207]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Adaptation occurs through the gradual modification of existing structures. Consequently, structures with similar internal organisation may have different functions in related organisms. This is the result of a single ancestral structure being adapted to function in different ways. The bones within <a href="/wiki/Bat" title="Bat">bat</a> wings, for example, are very similar to those in <a href="/wiki/Mouse" title="Mouse">mice</a> feet and <a href="/wiki/Primate" title="Primate">primate</a> hands, due to the descent of all these structures from a common mammalian ancestor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-208"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> However, since all living organisms are related to some extent,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Penny1999_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-Penny1999-209">[209]</a></sup> even organs that appear to have little or no structural similarity, such as <a href="/wiki/Arthropod" title="Arthropod">arthropod</a>, <a href="/wiki/Squid" title="Squid">squid</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vertebrate" title="Vertebrate">vertebrate</a> eyes, or the limbs and wings of arthropods and vertebrates, can depend on a common set of homologous genes that control their assembly and function; this is called <a href="/wiki/Deep_homology" title="Deep homology">deep homology</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-211"><a href="#cite_note-211">[211]</a></sup>
</p><p>During evolution, some structures may lose their original function and become <a href="/wiki/Vestigiality" title="Vestigiality">vestigial structures</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fong_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-Fong-212">[212]</a></sup> Such structures may have little or no function in a current species, yet have a clear function in ancestral species, or other closely related species. Examples include <a href="/wiki/Pseudogene" title="Pseudogene">pseudogenes</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-213"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> the non-functional remains of eyes in blind cave-dwelling fish,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> wings in flightless birds,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup> the presence of hip bones in whales and snakes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-transformation445_207-1"><a href="#cite_note-transformation445-207">[207]</a></sup> and sexual traits in organisms that reproduce via asexual reproduction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> Examples of <a href="/wiki/Human_vestigiality" title="Human vestigiality">vestigial structures in humans</a> include <a href="/wiki/Wisdom_tooth" title="Wisdom tooth">wisdom teeth</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-217"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Coccyx" title="Coccyx">coccyx</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fong_212-1"><a href="#cite_note-Fong-212">[212]</a></sup> the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vermiform_appendix" title="Vermiform appendix">vermiform appendix</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Fong_212-2"><a href="#cite_note-Fong-212">[212]</a></sup> and other behavioural vestiges such as <a href="/wiki/Goose_bumps" title="Goose bumps">goose bumps</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-218"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-219"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Primitive_reflexes" title="Primitive reflexes">primitive reflexes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-221"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup>
</p><p>However, many traits that appear to be simple adaptations are in fact <a href="/wiki/Exaptation" title="Exaptation">exaptations</a>: structures originally adapted for one function, but which coincidentally became somewhat useful for some other function in the process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20021235–1236_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20021235–1236-223">[223]</a></sup> One example is the African lizard <i>Holaspis guentheri</i>, which developed an extremely flat head for hiding in crevices, as can be seen by looking at its near relatives. However, in this species, the head has become so flattened that it assists in gliding from tree to tree—an exaptation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGould20021235–1236_223-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGould20021235–1236-223">[223]</a></sup> Within cells, <a href="/wiki/Molecular_machine" title="Molecular machine">molecular machines</a> such as the bacterial <a href="/wiki/Flagellum" title="Flagellum">flagella</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Translocase_of_the_inner_membrane" title="Translocase of the inner membrane">protein sorting machinery</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> evolved by the recruitment of several pre-existing proteins that previously had different functions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ScottEC_175-1"><a href="#cite_note-ScottEC-175">[175]</a></sup> Another example is the recruitment of enzymes from <a href="/wiki/Glycolysis" title="Glycolysis">glycolysis</a> and <a href="/wiki/Drug_metabolism" title="Drug metabolism">xenobiotic metabolism</a> to serve as structural proteins called <a href="/wiki/Crystallin" title="Crystallin">crystallins</a> within the lenses of organisms' eyes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-227"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup>
</p><p>An area of current investigation in evolutionary developmental biology is the developmental basis of adaptations and exaptations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> This research addresses the origin and evolution of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Embryogenesis" title="Embryogenesis">embryonic development</a> and how modifications of development and developmental processes produce novel features.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-229"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> These studies have shown that evolution can alter development to produce new structures, such as embryonic bone structures that develop into the jaw in other animals instead forming part of the <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_mammalian_auditory_ossicles" title="Evolution of mammalian auditory ossicles">middle ear in mammals</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[230]</a></sup> It is also possible for structures that have been lost in evolution to reappear due to changes in developmental genes, such as a mutation in chickens causing embryos to grow teeth similar to those of <a href="/wiki/Crocodile" title="Crocodile">crocodiles</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> It is now becoming clear that most alterations in the form of organisms are due to changes in a small set of conserved genes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Coevolution">Coevolution</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Coevolution" title="Coevolution">Coevolution</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2820" data-file-width="3384" decoding="async" height="183" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg/220px-Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg/330px-Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f7/Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg/440px-Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Thamnophis_sirtalis_sirtalis_Wooster.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_Garter_Snake" title="Common Garter Snake">Common garter snake</a> (<i>Thamnophis sirtalis sirtalis</i>) has evolved resistance to the <a href="/wiki/Anti-predator_adaptation" title="Anti-predator adaptation">defensive substance</a> <a href="/wiki/Tetrodotoxin" title="Tetrodotoxin">tetrodotoxin</a> in its amphibian prey.</div></div></div>
<p>Interactions between organisms can produce both conflict and cooperation. When the interaction is between pairs of species, such as a <a href="/wiki/Pathogen" title="Pathogen">pathogen</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Host_(biology)" title="Host (biology)">host</a>, or a predator and its prey, these species can develop matched sets of adaptations. Here, the evolution of one species causes adaptations in a second species. These changes in the second species then, in turn, cause new adaptations in the first species. This cycle of selection and response is called coevolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> An example is the production of <a href="/wiki/Tetrodotoxin" title="Tetrodotoxin">tetrodotoxin</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Rough-skinned_newt" title="Rough-skinned newt">rough-skinned newt</a> and the evolution of tetrodotoxin resistance in its predator, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Common_Garter_Snake" title="Common Garter Snake">common garter snake</a>. In this predator-prey pair, an <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_arms_race" title="Evolutionary arms race">evolutionary arms race</a> has produced high levels of toxin in the newt and correspondingly high levels of toxin resistance in the snake.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-234"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cooperation">Cooperation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Co-operation_(evolution)" title="Co-operation (evolution)">Co-operation (evolution)</a></div>
<p>Not all co-evolved interactions between species involve conflict.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> Many cases of mutually beneficial interactions have evolved. For instance, an extreme cooperation exists between plants and the <a href="/wiki/Mycorrhiza" title="Mycorrhiza">mycorrhizal fungi</a> that grow on their roots and aid the plant in absorbing nutrients from the soil.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> This is a <a href="/wiki/Reciprocity_(evolution)" title="Reciprocity (evolution)">reciprocal</a> relationship as the plants provide the fungi with sugars from <a href="/wiki/Photosynthesis" title="Photosynthesis">photosynthesis</a>. Here, the fungi actually grow inside plant cells, allowing them to exchange nutrients with their hosts, while sending <a href="/wiki/Signal_transduction" title="Signal transduction">signals</a> that suppress the plant <a href="/wiki/Immune_system" title="Immune system">immune system</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup>
</p><p>Coalitions between organisms of the same species have also evolved. An extreme case is the <a href="/wiki/Eusociality" title="Eusociality">eusociality</a> found in social insects, such as <a href="/wiki/Bee" title="Bee">bees</a>, <a href="/wiki/Termite" title="Termite">termites</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ant" title="Ant">ants</a>, where sterile insects feed and guard the small number of organisms in a <a href="/wiki/Colony_(biology)" title="Colony (biology)">colony</a> that are able to reproduce. On an even smaller scale, the somatic cells that make up the body of an animal limit their reproduction so they can maintain a stable organism, which then supports a small number of the animal's germ cells to produce offspring. Here, somatic cells respond to specific signals that instruct them whether to grow, remain as they are, or die. If cells ignore these signals and multiply inappropriately, their uncontrolled growth <a href="/wiki/Carcinogenesis" title="Carcinogenesis">causes cancer</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bertram_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bertram-238">[238]</a></sup>
</p><p>Such cooperation within species may have evolved through the process of <a href="/wiki/Kin_selection" title="Kin selection">kin selection</a>, which is where one organism acts to help raise a relative's offspring.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> This activity is selected for because if the <i>helping</i> individual contains alleles which promote the helping activity, it is likely that its kin will <i>also</i> contain these alleles and thus those alleles will be passed on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-240"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> Other processes that may promote cooperation include <a href="/wiki/Group_selection" title="Group selection">group selection</a>, where cooperation provides benefits to a group of organisms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Speciation">Speciation</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Speciation" title="Speciation">Speciation</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Assortative_mating" title="Assortative mating">Assortative mating</a> and <a href="/wiki/Panmixia" title="Panmixia">Panmixia</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:352px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Speciation_modes_edit.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="320" data-file-width="350" decoding="async" height="320" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Speciation_modes_edit.svg/350px-Speciation_modes_edit.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Speciation_modes_edit.svg/525px-Speciation_modes_edit.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Speciation_modes_edit.svg/700px-Speciation_modes_edit.svg.png 2x" width="350"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Speciation_modes_edit.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The four geographic modes of <a href="/wiki/Speciation" title="Speciation">speciation</a></div></div></div>
<p>Speciation is the process where a species diverges into two or more descendant species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gavrilets_242-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gavrilets-242">[242]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are multiple ways to define the concept of "species." The choice of definition is dependent on the particularities of the species concerned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Queiroz_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-Queiroz-243">[243]</a></sup> For example, some species concepts apply more readily toward sexually reproducing organisms while others lend themselves better toward asexual organisms. Despite the diversity of various species concepts, these various concepts can be placed into one of three broad philosophical approaches: interbreeding, ecological and phylogenetic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ereshefsky92_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ereshefsky92-244">[244]</a></sup> The <i>Biological Species Concept</i> is a classic example of the interbreeding approach. Defined by evolutionary biologist <a href="/wiki/Ernst_Mayr" title="Ernst Mayr">Ernst Mayr</a> in 1942, the BSC states that "species are groups of actually or potentially interbreeding natural populations, which are reproductively isolated from other such groups."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-245"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> Despite its wide and long-term use, the BSC like others is not without controversy, for example because these concepts cannot be applied to prokaryotes,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-246"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> and this is called the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Species_problem" title="Species problem">species problem</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Queiroz_243-1"><a href="#cite_note-Queiroz-243">[243]</a></sup> Some researchers have attempted a unifying monistic definition of species, while others adopt a pluralistic approach and suggest that there may be different ways to logically interpret the definition of a species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Queiroz_243-2"><a href="#cite_note-Queiroz-243">[243]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ereshefsky92_244-1"><a href="#cite_note-Ereshefsky92-244">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Reproductive_isolation" title="Reproductive isolation">Barriers to reproduction</a> between two diverging sexual populations are required for the populations to become new species. Gene flow may slow this process by spreading the new genetic variants also to the other populations. Depending on how far two species have diverged since their <a href="/wiki/Most_recent_common_ancestor" title="Most recent common ancestor">most recent common ancestor</a>, it may still be possible for them to produce offspring, as with horses and <a href="/wiki/Donkey" title="Donkey">donkeys</a> mating to produce <a href="/wiki/Mule" title="Mule">mules</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-247"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> Such hybrids are generally <a href="/wiki/Infertility" title="Infertility">infertile</a>. In this case, closely related species may regularly interbreed, but hybrids will be selected against and the species will remain distinct. However, viable hybrids are occasionally formed and these new species can either have properties intermediate between their parent species, or possess a totally new phenotype.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-248"><a href="#cite_note-248">[248]</a></sup> The importance of hybridisation in producing <a href="/wiki/Hybrid_speciation" title="Hybrid speciation">new species</a> of animals is unclear, although cases have been seen in many types of animals,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gray_tree_frog" title="Gray tree frog">gray tree frog</a> being a particularly well-studied example.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-250"><a href="#cite_note-250">[250]</a></sup>
</p><p>Speciation has been observed multiple times under both controlled laboratory conditions (see <a href="/wiki/Laboratory_experiments_of_speciation" title="Laboratory experiments of speciation">laboratory experiments of speciation</a>) and in nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[251]</a></sup> In sexually reproducing organisms, speciation results from reproductive isolation followed by genealogical divergence. There are four primary geographic modes of speciation. The most common in animals is <a href="/wiki/Allopatric_speciation" title="Allopatric speciation">allopatric speciation</a>, which occurs in populations initially isolated geographically, such as by <a href="/wiki/Habitat_fragmentation" title="Habitat fragmentation">habitat fragmentation</a> or migration. Selection under these conditions can produce very rapid changes in the appearance and behaviour of organisms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Losos1997_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-Losos1997-253">[253]</a></sup> As selection and drift act independently on populations isolated from the rest of their species, separation may eventually produce organisms that cannot interbreed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-254"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup>
</p><p>The second mode of speciation is <a href="/wiki/Peripatric_speciation" title="Peripatric speciation">peripatric speciation</a>, which occurs when small populations of organisms become isolated in a new environment. This differs from allopatric speciation in that the isolated populations are numerically much smaller than the parental population. Here, the <a href="/wiki/Founder_effect" title="Founder effect">founder effect</a> causes rapid speciation after an increase in <a href="/wiki/Inbreeding" title="Inbreeding">inbreeding</a> increases selection on homozygotes, leading to rapid genetic change.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-255"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup>
</p><p>The third mode is <a href="/wiki/Parapatric_speciation" title="Parapatric speciation">parapatric speciation</a>. This is similar to peripatric speciation in that a small population enters a new habitat, but differs in that there is no physical separation between these two populations. Instead, speciation results from the evolution of mechanisms that reduce gene flow between the two populations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gavrilets_242-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gavrilets-242">[242]</a></sup> Generally this occurs when there has been a drastic change in the environment within the parental species' habitat. One example is the grass <i><a href="/wiki/Anthoxanthum" title="Anthoxanthum">Anthoxanthum odoratum</a></i>, which can undergo parapatric speciation in response to localised metal pollution from mines.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> Here, plants evolve that have resistance to high levels of metals in the soil. Selection against interbreeding with the metal-sensitive parental population produced a gradual change in the flowering time of the metal-resistant plants, which eventually produced complete reproductive isolation. Selection against hybrids between the two populations may cause <a href="/wiki/Reinforcement_(speciation)" title="Reinforcement (speciation)">reinforcement</a>, which is the evolution of traits that promote mating within a species, as well as <a href="/wiki/Character_displacement" title="Character displacement">character displacement</a>, which is when two species become more distinct in appearance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[257]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:252px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Darwin%27s_finches.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="236" data-file-width="250" decoding="async" height="236" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/97/Darwin%27s_finches.jpeg" width="250"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Geographical_isolation" title="Geographical isolation">Geographical isolation</a> of <a href="/wiki/Darwin%27s_finches" title="Darwin's finches">finches</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Gal%C3%A1pagos_Islands" title="Galápagos Islands">Galápagos Islands</a> produced over a dozen new species.</div></div></div>
<p>Finally, in <a href="/wiki/Sympatric_speciation" title="Sympatric speciation">sympatric speciation</a> species diverge without geographic isolation or changes in habitat. This form is rare since even a small amount of gene flow may remove genetic differences between parts of a population.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-258"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> Generally, sympatric speciation in animals requires the evolution of both <a href="/wiki/Polymorphism_(biology)" title="Polymorphism (biology)">genetic differences</a> and <a href="/wiki/Assortative_mating" title="Assortative mating">nonrandom mating</a>, to allow reproductive isolation to evolve.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-259"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup>
</p><p>One type of sympatric speciation involves <a href="/wiki/Crossbreed" title="Crossbreed">crossbreeding</a> of two related species to produce a new hybrid species. This is not common in animals as animal hybrids are usually sterile. This is because during <a href="/wiki/Meiosis" title="Meiosis">meiosis</a> the <a href="/wiki/Homologous_chromosome" title="Homologous chromosome">homologous chromosomes</a> from each parent are from different species and cannot successfully pair. However, it is more common in plants because plants often double their number of chromosomes, to form <a href="/wiki/Polyploidy" title="Polyploidy">polyploids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-260"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> This allows the chromosomes from each parental species to form matching pairs during meiosis, since each parent's chromosomes are represented by a pair already.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-261"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> An example of such a speciation event is when the plant species <i><a href="/wiki/Arabidopsis_thaliana" title="Arabidopsis thaliana">Arabidopsis thaliana</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Arabidopsis_arenosa" title="Arabidopsis arenosa">Arabidopsis arenosa</a></i> crossbred to give the new species <i>Arabidopsis suecica</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-262"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> This happened about 20,000 years ago,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup> and the speciation process has been repeated in the laboratory, which allows the study of the genetic mechanisms involved in this process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup> Indeed, chromosome doubling within a species may be a common cause of reproductive isolation, as half the doubled chromosomes will be unmatched when breeding with undoubled organisms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Semon_265-0"><a href="#cite_note-Semon-265">[265]</a></sup>
</p><p>Speciation events are important in the theory of <a href="/wiki/Punctuated_equilibrium" title="Punctuated equilibrium">punctuated equilibrium</a>, which accounts for the pattern in the fossil record of short "bursts" of evolution interspersed with relatively long periods of stasis, where species remain relatively unchanged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> In this theory, speciation and rapid evolution are linked, with natural selection and genetic drift acting most strongly on organisms undergoing speciation in novel habitats or small populations. As a result, the periods of stasis in the fossil record correspond to the parental population and the organisms undergoing speciation and rapid evolution are found in small populations or geographically restricted habitats and therefore rarely being preserved as fossils.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gould_1994_179-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gould_1994-179">[179]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Extinction">Extinction</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Extinction" title="Extinction">Extinction</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1552" data-file-width="2400" decoding="async" height="142" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg/220px-Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg/330px-Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ab/Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg/440px-Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Palais_de_la_Decouverte_Tyrannosaurus_rex_p1050042.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Tyrannosaurus_rex" title="Tyrannosaurus rex">Tyrannosaurus rex</a></i>. Non-<a href="/wiki/Bird" title="Bird">avian</a> <a href="/wiki/Dinosaur" title="Dinosaur">dinosaurs</a> died out in the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a> at the end of the <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous" title="Cretaceous">Cretaceous</a> period.</div></div></div>
<p>Extinction is the disappearance of an entire species. Extinction is not an unusual event, as species regularly appear through speciation and disappear through extinction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup> Nearly all animal and plant species that have lived on Earth are now extinct,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-268"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> and extinction appears to be the ultimate fate of all species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-269"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> These extinctions have happened continuously throughout the history of life, although the rate of extinction spikes in occasional mass <a href="/wiki/Extinction_event" title="Extinction event">extinction events</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raup_1994_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-Raup_1994-270">[270]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Cretaceous%E2%80%93Paleogene_extinction_event" title="Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event">Cretaceous–Paleogene extinction event</a>, during which the non-avian dinosaurs became extinct, is the most well-known, but the earlier <a href="/wiki/Permian%E2%80%93Triassic_extinction_event" title="Permian–Triassic extinction event">Permian–Triassic extinction event</a> was even more severe, with approximately 96% of all marine species driven to extinction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raup_1994_270-1"><a href="#cite_note-Raup_1994-270">[270]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Holocene_extinction" title="Holocene extinction">Holocene extinction event</a> is an ongoing mass extinction associated with humanity's expansion across the globe over the past few thousand years. Present-day extinction rates are 100–1000 times greater than the background rate and up to 30% of current species may be extinct by the mid 21st century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-271"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> Human activities are now the primary cause of the ongoing extinction event;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[272]</a></sup>
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-273"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Global_warming" title="Global warming">global warming</a> may further accelerate it in the future.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup> Despite the estimated extinction of more than 99 percent of all species that ever lived on Earth,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StearnsStearns1999_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-StearnsStearns1999-275">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20141108-MJN_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20141108-MJN-276">[276]</a></sup> about 1 trillion species are estimated to be on Earth currently with only one-thousandth of one percent described.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NSF-2016002_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-NSF-2016002-277">[277]</a></sup>
</p><p>The role of extinction in evolution is not very well understood and may depend on which type of extinction is considered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Raup_1994_270-2"><a href="#cite_note-Raup_1994-270">[270]</a></sup> The causes of the continuous "low-level" extinction events, which form the majority of extinctions, may be the result of competition between species for limited resources (the <a href="/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle" title="Competitive exclusion principle">competitive exclusion principle</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kutschera_57-1"><a href="#cite_note-Kutschera-57">[57]</a></sup> If one species can out-compete another, this could produce species selection, with the fitter species surviving and the other species being driven to extinction.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gould_124-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gould-124">[124]</a></sup> The intermittent mass extinctions are also important, but instead of acting as a selective force, they drastically reduce diversity in a nonspecific manner and promote bursts of rapid evolution and speciation in survivors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolutionary_history_of_life">Evolutionary history of life</span></h2>
<div style="float: right;">

id="Scale" style="padding:0;margin:0.7em 0 0.7em 0;width:4.2em;position:relative;float:left;font-size:100%;height:50em;border-right:1px solid #242020"><div style="z-index:10;font-size:90%;color:black;display:block;line-height:105%;bottom:0"><a href="/wiki/Mesoarchean" title="Mesoarchean">Pongola glaciation</a>*</div></div></td></tr></tbody></table><table role="presentation" style="position:absolute;z-index:15;top:25.330em;left:0em;transform:translateY(-50%);padding:0;margin:0;font-size:100%"><tbody><tr><td style="padding:0;text-align:left;vertical-align:middle"><span style="color:black">←</span></td><td style="padding:0;text-align:left;vertical-align:middle"><div class="annot-nudge" style="font-size:100%;float:left;position:relative;top:0.2em"><div style="z-index:10;font-size:90%;color:black;display:block;line-height:105%;bottom:0"><a href="/wiki/Great_Oxidation_Event" title="Great Oxidation Event">Atmospheric oxygen</a></div></div></td></tr></tbody></table><table role="presentation"
