</div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Evolutionary history of life">Evolutionary history of life</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_the_evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Timeline of the evolutionary history of life">Timeline of the evolutionary history of life</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Origin_of_life">Origin of life</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Abiogenesis" title="Abiogenesis">Abiogenesis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Earliest_known_life_forms" title="Earliest known life forms">Earliest known life forms</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panspermia" title="Panspermia">Panspermia</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/RNA_world_hypothesis" title="RNA world hypothesis">RNA world hypothesis</a></div>
<p>The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Age_of_the_Earth" title="Age of the Earth">Earth</a> is about 4.54 billion years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-USGS1997_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-USGS1997-279">[279]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dalrymple_2001_205–221_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dalrymple_2001_205–221-280">[280]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Elsevier_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-Elsevier-281">[281]</a></sup> The earliest undisputed evidence of life on Earth dates from at least 3.5 billion years ago,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Origin1_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-Origin1-13">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-RavenJohnson2002_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-RavenJohnson2002-282">[282]</a></sup> during the <a href="/wiki/Eoarchean" title="Eoarchean">Eoarchean</a> Era after a geological <a href="/wiki/Crust_(geology)" title="Crust (geology)">crust</a> started to solidify following the earlier molten <a href="/wiki/Hadean" title="Hadean">Hadean</a> Eon. Microbial mat fossils have been found in 3.48 billion-year-old sandstone in Western Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-20131113_15-1"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20131113-15">[15]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-TG-20131113-JP_16-1"><a href="#cite_note-TG-20131113-JP-16">[16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AST-20131108_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-AST-20131108-17">[17]</a></sup> Other early physical evidence of a biogenic substance is graphite in 3.7 billion-year-old <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metasediment" title="Metasediment">metasedimentary rocks</a> discovered in Western Greenland<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NG-20131208_14-1"><a href="#cite_note-NG-20131208-14">[14]</a></sup> as well as "remains of <a href="/wiki/Biotic_material" title="Biotic material">biotic life</a>" found in 4.1 billion-year-old rocks in Western Australia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-20151019_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20151019-283">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PNAS-20151014-pdf_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-PNAS-20151014-pdf-284">[284]</a></sup> Commenting on the Australian findings, <a href="/wiki/Stephen_Blair_Hedges" title="Stephen Blair Hedges">Stephen Blair Hedges</a> wrote, "If life arose relatively quickly on Earth, then it could be common in the universe."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-AP-20151019_283-1"><a href="#cite_note-AP-20151019-283">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup>  In July 2016, scientists reported identifying a set of 355 <a href="/wiki/Gene" title="Gene">genes</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Last_universal_common_ancestor" title="Last universal common ancestor">last universal common ancestor</a> (LUCA) of all organisms living on Earth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20160725_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20160725-286">[286]</a></sup>
</p><p>More than 99 percent of all species, amounting to over five billion species,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Book-Biology_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-Book-Biology-287">[287]</a></sup> that ever lived on Earth are estimated to be extinct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-StearnsStearns1999_275-1"><a href="#cite_note-StearnsStearns1999-275">[275]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20141108-MJN_276-1"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20141108-MJN-276">[276]</a></sup> Estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 10 million to 14 million,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-PLoS-20110823_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-PLoS-20110823-288">[288]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MillerSpoolman2012_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-MillerSpoolman2012-289">[289]</a></sup> of which about 1.9 million are estimated to have been named<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Chapman2009_290-0"><a href="#cite_note-Chapman2009-290">[290]</a></sup> and 1.6 million documented in a central database to date,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-col2016_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-col2016-291">[291]</a></sup> leaving at least 80 percent not yet described.
</p><p>Highly energetic chemistry is thought to have produced a self-replicating molecule around 4 billion years ago, and half a billion years later the last common ancestor of all life existed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Doolittle_2000_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-Doolittle_2000-11">[11]</a></sup> The current scientific consensus is that the complex biochemistry that makes up life came from simpler chemical reactions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-292"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BBC-20201111_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-BBC-20201111-293">[293]</a></sup> The beginning of life may have included self-replicating molecules such as <a href="/wiki/RNA" title="RNA">RNA</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> and the assembly of simple cells.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Common_descent">Common descent</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Common_descent" title="Common descent">Common descent</a> and <a href="/wiki/Evidence_of_common_descent" title="Evidence of common descent">Evidence of common descent</a></div>
<p>All organisms on Earth are descended from a common ancestor or ancestral <a href="/wiki/Gene_pool" title="Gene pool">gene pool</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Penny1999_209-1"><a href="#cite_note-Penny1999-209">[209]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> Current species are a stage in the process of evolution, with their diversity the product of a long series of speciation and extinction events.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> The common descent of organisms was first deduced from four simple facts about organisms: First, they have geographic distributions that cannot be explained by local adaptation. Second, the diversity of life is not a set of completely unique organisms, but organisms that share morphological similarities. Third, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vestigial_trait" title="Vestigial trait">vestigial traits</a> with no clear purpose resemble functional ancestral traits. Fourth, organisms can be classified using these similarities into a hierarchy of nested groups, similar to a family tree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:322px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ape_skeletons.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="588" data-file-width="1081" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ape_skeletons.png/320px-Ape_skeletons.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ape_skeletons.png/480px-Ape_skeletons.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/Ape_skeletons.png/640px-Ape_skeletons.png 2x" width="320"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ape_skeletons.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/Ape" title="Ape">hominoids</a> are descendants of a <a href="/wiki/Common_descent" title="Common descent">common ancestor</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Modern research has suggested that, due to <a href="/wiki/Horizontal_gene_transfer" title="Horizontal gene transfer">horizontal gene transfer</a>, this "tree of life" may be more complicated than a simple branching tree since some genes have spread independently between distantly related species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-299"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> To solve this problem and others, some authors prefer to use the "<a href="/wiki/Coral_of_life" title="Coral of life">Coral of life</a>" as a metaphor or a mathematical model to illustrate the evolution of life. This view dates back to an idea briefly mentioned by Darwin but later abandoned.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bnotebook_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bnotebook-301">[301]</a></sup>
</p><p>Past species have also left records of their evolutionary history. Fossils, along with the comparative anatomy of present-day organisms, constitute the morphological, or anatomical, record.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Jablonski_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-Jablonski-302">[302]</a></sup> By comparing the anatomies of both modern and extinct species, palaeontologists can infer the lineages of those species. However, this approach is most successful for organisms that had hard body parts, such as shells, bones or teeth. Further, as prokaryotes such as bacteria and archaea share a limited set of common morphologies, their fossils do not provide information on their ancestry.
</p><p>More recently, evidence for common descent has come from the study of biochemical similarities between organisms. For example, all living cells use the same basic set of nucleotides and <a href="/wiki/Amino_acid" title="Amino acid">amino acids</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-303"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> The development of <a href="/wiki/Molecular_genetics" title="Molecular genetics">molecular genetics</a> has revealed the record of evolution left in organisms' genomes: dating when species diverged through the <a href="/wiki/Molecular_clock" title="Molecular clock">molecular clock</a> produced by mutations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-304"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup> For example, these DNA sequence comparisons have revealed that humans and chimpanzees share 98% of their genomes and analysing the few areas where they differ helps shed light on when the common ancestor of these species existed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Evolution_of_life">Evolution of life</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Evolutionary history of life">Evolutionary history of life</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Timeline_of_evolutionary_history_of_life" title="Timeline of evolutionary history of life">Timeline of evolutionary history of life</a></div>

alt="Planctomycetota" coords="229,68,300,77" href="/wiki/Planctomycetota" shape="rect" title="Planctomycetota"/><area alt="Spirochaetota" coords="233,85,292,94" href="/wiki/Spirochaetota" shape="rect" title="Spirochaetota"/><area alt="Fusobacteriota" coords="233,107,291,114" href="/wiki/Fusobacteriota" shape="rect" title="Fusobacteriota"/><area alt="Cyanobacteria" coords="232,125,313,146" href="/wiki/Cyanobacteria" shape="rect" title="Cyanobacteria"/><area alt="Thermophiles" coords="220,150,293,168" href="/wiki/Thermophiles" shape="rect" title="Thermophiles"/><area alt="Acidobacteriota" coords="194,177,257,185" href="/wiki/Acidobacteriota" shape="rect" title="Acidobacteriota"/><area alt="Pseudomonadota" coords="118,188,183,195" href="/wiki/Pseudomonadota" shape="rect" title="Pseudomonadota"/></map><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="741" data-file-width="1122" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png/320px-Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png/480px-Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/78/Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png/640px-Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png 2x" usemap="#ImageMap_0a164291f73509fe" width="320"/></div> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Collapsed_tree_labels_simplified.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Phylogenetic_tree" title="Phylogenetic tree">Evolutionary tree</a> showing the divergence of modern species from their common ancestor in the centre.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ciccarelli_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ciccarelli-306">[306]</a></sup> The three <a href="/wiki/Domain_(biology)" title="Domain (biology)">domains</a> are coloured, with <a href="/wiki/Bacteria" title="Bacteria">bacteria</a> blue, <a href="/wiki/Archaea" title="Archaea">archaea</a> green and <a href="/wiki/Eukaryote" title="Eukaryote">eukaryotes</a> red.</div></div></div>
<p>Prokaryotes inhabited the Earth from approximately 3–4 billion years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavalier-Smith_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-Cavalier-Smith-307">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-308"><a href="#cite_note-308">[308]</a></sup> No obvious changes in morphology or cellular organisation occurred in these organisms over the next few billion years.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup> The eukaryotic cells emerged between 1.6 and 2.7 billion years ago. The next major change in cell structure came when bacteria were engulfed by eukaryotic cells, in a cooperative association called <a href="/wiki/Endosymbiont" title="Endosymbiont">endosymbiosis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rgruqh_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-rgruqh-310">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Dyall_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-Dyall-311">[311]</a></sup> The engulfed bacteria and the host cell then underwent coevolution, with the bacteria evolving into either mitochondria or <a href="/wiki/Hydrogenosome" title="Hydrogenosome">hydrogenosomes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> Another engulfment of <a href="/wiki/Cyanobacteria" title="Cyanobacteria">cyanobacterial</a>-like organisms led to the formation of chloroplasts in algae and plants.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup>
</p><p>The history of life was that of the <a href="/wiki/Unicellular_organism" title="Unicellular organism">unicellular</a> eukaryotes, prokaryotes and archaea until about 610 million years ago when multicellular organisms began to appear in the oceans in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ediacara_biota" title="Ediacara biota">Ediacaran</a> period.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Cavalier-Smith_307-1"><a href="#cite_note-Cavalier-Smith-307">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-314"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Multicellular_evolution" title="Multicellular evolution">evolution of multicellularity</a> occurred in multiple independent events, in organisms as diverse as <a href="/wiki/Sponge" title="Sponge">sponges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brown_algae" title="Brown algae">brown algae</a>, cyanobacteria, <a href="/wiki/Slime_mold" title="Slime mold">slime moulds</a> and <a href="/wiki/Myxobacteria" title="Myxobacteria">myxobacteria</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-315"><a href="#cite_note-315">[315]</a></sup> In January 2016, scientists reported that, about 800 million years ago, a minor genetic change in a single molecule called GK-PID may have allowed organisms to go from a single cell organism to one of many cells.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-NYT-20160107_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-NYT-20160107-316">[316]</a></sup>
</p><p>Soon after the emergence of these first multicellular organisms, a remarkable amount of biological diversity appeared over approximately 10 million years, in an event called the <a href="/wiki/Cambrian_explosion" title="Cambrian explosion">Cambrian explosion</a>. Here, the majority of <a href="/wiki/Phylum" title="Phylum">types</a> of modern animals appeared in the fossil record, as well as unique lineages that subsequently became extinct.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Valentine_1999_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-Valentine_1999-317">[317]</a></sup> Various triggers for the Cambrian explosion have been proposed, including the accumulation of oxygen in the atmosphere from photosynthesis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup>
</p><p>About 500 million years ago, plants and fungi colonised the land and were soon followed by arthropods and other animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-319"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup> Insects were particularly successful and even today make up the majority of animal species.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Amphibian" title="Amphibian">Amphibians</a> first appeared around 364 million years ago, followed by early <a href="/wiki/Amniote" title="Amniote">amniotes</a> and birds around 155 million years ago (both from "<a href="/wiki/Reptile" title="Reptile">reptile</a>"-like lineages), <a href="/wiki/Mammal" title="Mammal">mammals</a> around 129 million years ago, <a href="/wiki/Homininae" title="Homininae">Homininae</a> around 10 million years ago and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anatomically_modern_humans" title="Anatomically modern humans">modern humans</a> around 250,000 years ago.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-322"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-323"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup> However, despite the evolution of these large animals, smaller organisms similar to the types that evolved early in this process continue to be highly successful and dominate the Earth, with the majority of both biomass and species being prokaryotes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Schloss_186-1"><a href="#cite_note-Schloss-186">[186]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Applications">Applications</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Applications_of_evolution" title="Applications of evolution">Applications of evolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Selective_breeding" title="Selective breeding">Selective breeding</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_computation" title="Evolutionary computation">Evolutionary computation</a></div>
<p>Concepts and models used in evolutionary biology, such as natural selection, have many applications.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bull_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bull-324">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>Artificial selection is the intentional selection of traits in a population of organisms. This has been used for thousands of years in the <a href="/wiki/Domestication" title="Domestication">domestication</a> of plants and animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-325"><a href="#cite_note-325">[325]</a></sup> More recently, such selection has become a vital part of <a href="/wiki/Genetic_engineering" title="Genetic engineering">genetic engineering</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Selectable_marker" title="Selectable marker">selectable markers</a> such as antibiotic resistance genes being used to manipulate DNA. Proteins with valuable properties have evolved by repeated rounds of mutation and selection (for example modified enzymes and new <a href="/wiki/Antibody" title="Antibody">antibodies</a>) in a process called <a href="/wiki/Directed_evolution" title="Directed evolution">directed evolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>Understanding the changes that have occurred during an organism's evolution can reveal the genes needed to construct parts of the body, genes which may be involved in human <a href="/wiki/Genetic_disorder" title="Genetic disorder">genetic disorders</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-327"><a href="#cite_note-327">[327]</a></sup> For example, the <a href="/wiki/Mexican_tetra" title="Mexican tetra">Mexican tetra</a> is an <a href="/wiki/Albinism" title="Albinism">albino</a> cavefish that lost its eyesight during evolution. Breeding together different populations of this blind fish produced some offspring with functional eyes, since different mutations had occurred in the isolated populations that had evolved in different caves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[328]</a></sup> This helped identify genes required for vision and pigmentation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>Evolutionary theory has many <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_therapy" title="Evolutionary therapy">applications in medicine</a>. Many human diseases are not static phenomena, but capable of evolution. Viruses, bacteria, fungi and <a href="/wiki/Cancer" title="Cancer">cancers</a> evolve to be resistant to host <a href="/wiki/Immune_system" title="Immune system">immune defences</a>, as well as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pharmaceutical_drug" title="Pharmaceutical drug">pharmaceutical drugs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-330"><a href="#cite_note-330">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-331"><a href="#cite_note-331">[331]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-332"><a href="#cite_note-332">[332]</a></sup> These same problems occur in agriculture with <a href="/wiki/Pesticide" title="Pesticide">pesticide</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-333"><a href="#cite_note-333">[333]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Herbicide" title="Herbicide">herbicide</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[334]</a></sup> resistance. It is possible that we are facing the end of the effective life of most of available antibiotics<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-335"><a href="#cite_note-335">[335]</a></sup> and predicting the evolution and evolvability<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[336]</a></sup> of our pathogens and devising strategies to slow or circumvent it is requiring deeper knowledge of the complex forces driving evolution at the molecular level.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-337"><a href="#cite_note-337">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p>In <a href="/wiki/Computer_science" title="Computer science">computer science</a>, simulations of evolution using <a href="/wiki/Evolutionary_algorithm" title="Evolutionary algorithm">evolutionary algorithms</a> and <a href="/wiki/Artificial_life" title="Artificial life">artificial life</a> started in the 1960s and were extended with simulation of artificial selection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-338"><a href="#cite_note-338">[338]</a></sup> Artificial evolution became a widely recognised optimisation method as a result of the work of <a href="/wiki/Ingo_Rechenberg" title="Ingo Rechenberg">Ingo Rechenberg</a> in the 1960s. He used <a href="/wiki/Evolution_strategy" title="Evolution strategy">evolution strategies</a> to solve complex engineering problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[339]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Genetic_algorithm" title="Genetic algorithm">Genetic algorithms</a> in particular became popular through the writing of <a href="/wiki/John_Henry_Holland" title="John Henry Holland">John Henry Holland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-340"><a href="#cite_note-340">[340]</a></sup> Practical applications also include <a href="/wiki/Genetic_programming" title="Genetic programming">automatic evolution of computer programmes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-341"><a href="#cite_note-341">[341]</a></sup> Evolutionary algorithms are now used to solve multi-dimensional problems more efficiently than software produced by human designers and also to optimise the design of systems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[342]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Social_and_cultural_responses">Social and cultural responses</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Social_effects_of_evolutionary_theory" title="Social effects of evolutionary theory">Social effects of evolutionary theory</a>, <a href="/wiki/1860_Oxford_evolution_debate" title="1860 Oxford evolution debate">1860 Oxford evolution debate</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rejection_of_evolution_by_religious_groups" title="Rejection of evolution by religious groups">Rejection of evolution by religious groups</a>, <a href="/wiki/Objections_to_evolution" title="Objections to evolution">Objections to evolution</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Evolution_in_fiction" title="Evolution in fiction">Evolution in fiction</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_(1871).jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2782" data-file-width="2068" decoding="async" height="229" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_%281871%29.jpg/170px-Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_%281871%29.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_%281871%29.jpg/255px-Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_%281871%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_%281871%29.jpg/340px-Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_%281871%29.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Editorial_cartoon_depicting_Charles_Darwin_as_an_ape_(1871).jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>As evolution became widely accepted in the 1870s, <a href="/wiki/Caricature" title="Caricature">caricatures</a> of Charles Darwin with an <a href="/wiki/Ape" title="Ape">ape</a> or <a href="/wiki/Monkey" title="Monkey">monkey</a> body symbolised evolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-343"><a href="#cite_note-343">[343]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>In the 19th century, particularly after the publication of <i>On the Origin of Species</i> in 1859, the idea that life had evolved was an active source of academic debate centred on the philosophical, social and religious implications of evolution. Today, the modern evolutionary synthesis is accepted by a vast majority of scientists.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Kutschera_57-2"><a href="#cite_note-Kutschera-57">[57]</a></sup> However, evolution remains a contentious concept for some <a href="/wiki/Theism" title="Theism">theists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[344]</a></sup>
</p><p>While <a href="/wiki/Level_of_support_for_evolution#Religious" title="Level of support for evolution">various religions and denominations</a> have reconciled their beliefs with evolution through concepts such as <a href="/wiki/Theistic_evolution" title="Theistic evolution">theistic evolution</a>, there are <a href="/wiki/Creationism" title="Creationism">creationists</a> who believe that evolution is contradicted by the <a href="/wiki/Creation_myth" title="Creation myth">creation myths</a> found in their <a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religions</a> and who raise various <a href="/wiki/Objections_to_evolution" title="Objections to evolution">objections to evolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ScottEC_175-2"><a href="#cite_note-ScottEC-175">[175]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Ross2005_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-Ross2005-345">[345]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-346"><a href="#cite_note-346">[346]</a></sup> As had been demonstrated by responses to the publication of <i><a href="/wiki/Vestiges_of_the_Natural_History_of_Creation" title="Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation">Vestiges of the Natural History of Creation</a></i> in 1844, the most controversial aspect of evolutionary biology is the implication of <a href="/wiki/Human_evolution" title="Human evolution">human evolution</a> that humans share common ancestry with apes and that the mental and <a href="/wiki/Evolution_of_morality" title="Evolution of morality">moral faculties</a> of humanity have the same types of natural causes as other inherited traits in animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-347"><a href="#cite_note-347">[347]</a></sup> In some countries, notably the United States, these tensions between science and religion have fuelled the current creation–evolution controversy, a religious conflict focusing on <a href="/wiki/Politics" title="Politics">politics</a> and <a href="/wiki/Creation_and_evolution_in_public_education" title="Creation and evolution in public education">public education</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[348]</a></sup> While other scientific fields such as <a href="/wiki/Physical_cosmology" title="Physical cosmology">cosmology</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wmap_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-wmap-349">[349]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Earth_science" title="Earth science">Earth science</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-zircon_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-zircon-350">[350]</a></sup> also conflict with literal interpretations of many <a href="/wiki/Religious_text" title="Religious text">religious texts</a>, evolutionary biology experiences significantly more opposition from religious literalists.
</p><p>The teaching of evolution in American secondary school biology classes was uncommon in most of the first half of the 20th century. The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Scopes_Trial" title="Scopes Trial">Scopes Trial</a> decision of 1925 caused the subject to become very rare in American secondary biology textbooks for a generation, but it was gradually re-introduced later and became legally protected with the 1968 <i><a href="/wiki/Epperson_v._Arkansas" title="Epperson v. Arkansas">Epperson v. Arkansas</a></i> decision. Since then, the competing religious belief of <a href="/wiki/Creationism" title="Creationism">creationism</a> was legally disallowed in secondary school curricula in various decisions in the 1970s and 1980s, but it returned in <a href="/wiki/Pseudoscience" title="Pseudoscience">pseudoscientific</a> form as <a href="/wiki/Intelligent_design" title="Intelligent design">intelligent design</a> (ID), to be excluded once again in the 2005 <i><a href="/wiki/Kitzmiller_v._Dover_Area_School_District" title="Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District">Kitzmiller v. Dover Area School District</a></i> case.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-BioScience_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-BioScience-351">[351]</a></sup> The debate over Darwin's ideas did not generate significant controversy in China.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-jin2019_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-jin2019-352">[352]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>

</li>

</li>
<li id="cite_note-Futuyma2017c-3"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Futuyma2017c_3-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Futuyma2017c_3-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFFutuymaKirkpatrick2017">Futuyma &amp; Kirkpatrick 2017</a>, pp. 79–102, Chapter 4: Mutation and Variation</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-Scott-Phillips-4"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Scott-Phillips_4-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFScott-PhillipsLalandShukerDickins2014">Scott-Phillips, Thomas C.; <a href="/wiki/Kevin_Laland" title="Kevin Laland">Laland, Kevin N.</a>; Shuker, David M.; Dickins, Thomas E.; <a href="/wiki/Stuart_West" title="Stuart West">West, Stuart A.</a> (May 2014). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4261998" rel="nofollow">"The Niche Construction Perspective: A Critical Appraisal"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Evolution_(journal)" title="Evolution (journal)">Evolution</a></i>. <b>68</b> (5): 1231–1243. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1111%2Fevo.12332" rel="nofollow">10.1111/evo.12332</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0014-3820" rel="nofollow">0014-3820</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4261998" rel="nofollow">4261998</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24325256" rel="nofollow">24325256</a>. <q>Evolutionary processes are generally thought of as processes by which these changes occur. Four such processes are widely recognized: natural selection (in the broad sense, to include sexual selection), genetic drift, mutation, and migration (Fisher 1930; Haldane 1932). The latter two generate variation; the first two sort it.</q></cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Evolution&amp;rft.atitle=The+Niche+Construction+Perspective%3A+A+Critical+Appraisal&amp;rft.volume=68&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.pages=1231-1243&amp;rft.date=2014-05&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4261998%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft.issn=0014-3820&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F24325256&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1111%2Fevo.12332&amp;rft.aulast=Scott-Phillips&amp;rft.aufirst=Thomas+C.&amp;rft.au=Laland%2C+Kevin+N.&amp;rft.au=Shuker%2C+David+M.&amp;rft.au=Dickins%2C+Thomas+E.&amp;rft.au=West%2C+Stuart+A.&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC4261998&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-5"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-5">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFHallHallgrímsson2008">Hall &amp; Hallgrímsson 2008</a>, pp. 3–5</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-12"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-12">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGlansdorffYing_XuLabedan2008">Glansdorff, Nicolas; <li id="cite_note-TG-20131113-JP-16"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-TG-20131113-JP_16-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-TG-20131113-JP_16-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFPearlman2013">Pearlman, Jonathan (13 November 2013). <a class="external text" href="https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/science/science-news/10445788/Oldest-signs-of-life-on-Earth-found.html" rel="nofollow">"Oldest signs of life on Earth found"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph" title="The Daily Telegraph">The Daily Telegraph</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-AST-20131108-17"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-AST-20131108_17-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-AST-20131108_17-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFNoffkeChristianWaceyHazen2013"><a href="/wiki/Nora_Noffke" title="Nora Noffke">Noffke, Nora</a>; Christian, Daniel; Wacey, David; <a href="/wiki/Robert_Hazen" title="Robert Hazen">Hazen, Robert M.</a> (16 November 2013). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3870916" rel="nofollow">"Microbially Induced Sedimentary Structures Recording an Ancient Ecosystem in the <i>ca.</i> 3.48 Billion-Year-Old Dresser Formation, Pilbara, Western Australia"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Astrobiology_(journal)" title="Astrobiology (journal)">Astrobiology</a></i>. <b>13</b> (12): 1103–1124. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2013AsBio..13.1103N" rel="nofollow">2013AsBio..13.1103N</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1089%2Fast.2013.1030" rel="nofollow">10.1089/ast.2013.1030</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1531-1074" rel="nofollow">1531-1074</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC <li id="cite_note-Jablonka07-37"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Jablonka07_37-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFJablonkaLamb2007"><a href="/wiki/Eva_Jablonka" title="Eva Jablonka">Jablonka, Eva</a>; <a href="/wiki/Marion_J._Lamb" title="Marion J. <li id="cite_note-Darwin91-38"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Darwin91_38-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFBurkhardtSmith1991">Burkhardt &amp; Smith 1991</a>
<ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation web cs1"><a class="external text" href="http://www.darwinproject.ac.uk/letter/entry-2532" rel="nofollow">"Darwin, C. R. to Lubbock, John"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Correspondence_of_Charles_Darwin#Darwin_Correspondence_Project_website" title="Correspondence of Charles Darwin">Darwin Correspondence Project</a></i>. Cambridge: <a href="/wiki/University_of_Cambridge" title="University of Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20141215213940/http://www.darwinproject.ac.uk/letter/entry-2532" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 15 December 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. Retrieved <span class="nowrap">1 December</span> 2014</span>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=unknown&amp;rft.jtitle=Darwin+Correspondence+Project&amp;rft.atitle=Darwin%2C+C.+R.+to+Lubbock%2C+John&amp;rft_id=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.darwinproject.ac.uk%2Fletter%2Fentry-2532&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span> Letter 2532, 22 November 1859.</li></ul>
</span></li>

<li id="cite_note-51"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-51">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFStamhuisMeijerZevenhuizen1999">Stamhuis, Ida H.; Meijer, Onno G.; Zevenhuizen, Erik J. A. (June 1999). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/sim_isis_1999-06_90_2/page/238" rel="nofollow">"Hugo de Vries on Heredity, 1889–1903: Statistics, Mendelian Laws, Pangenes, Mutations"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Isis_(journal)" title="Isis (journal)">Isis</a></i>. <b>90</b> (2): 238–267. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1086%2F384323" rel="nofollow">10.1086/384323</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/JSTOR_(identifier)" title="JSTOR (identifier)">JSTOR</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.jstor.org/stable/237050" rel="nofollow">237050</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10439561" rel="nofollow">10439561</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:20200394" rel="nofollow">20200394</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Isis&amp;rft.atitle=Hugo+de+Vries+on+Heredity%2C+1889%E2%80%931903%3A+Statistics%2C+Mendelian+Laws%2C+Pangenes%2C+Mutations&amp;rft.volume=90&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=238-267&amp;rft.date=1999-06&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F10439561&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A20200394%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.jstor.org%2Fstable%2F237050%23id-name%3DJSTOR&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1086%2F384323&amp;rft.aulast=Stamhuis&amp;rft.aufirst=Ida+H.&amp;rft.au=Meijer%2C+Onno+G.&amp;rft.au=Zevenhuizen%2C+Erik+J.+A.&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fsim_isis_1999-06_90_2%2Fpage%2F238&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Watson53-54"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Watson53_54-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWatsonCrick1953"><a href="/wiki/James_Watson" title="James Watson">Watson, J. D.</a>; <a href="/wiki/Francis_Crick" title="Francis Crick">Crick, F. H. C.</a> (25 April 1953). <a class="external text" href="http://profiles.nlm.nih.gov/SC/B/B/Y/W/_/scbbyw.pdf" rel="nofollow">"Molecular Structure of Nucleic Acids: A Structure for Deoxyribose Nucleic Acid"</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span>. <i><a href="/wiki/Nature_(journal)" title="Nature (journal)">Nature</a></i>. <b>171</b> (4356): 737–738. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/1953Natur.171..737W" rel="nofollow">1953Natur.171..737W</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2F171737a0" rel="nofollow">10.1038/171737a0</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0028-0836" rel="nofollow">0028-0836</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/13054692" rel="nofollow">13054692</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:4253007" rel="nofollow">4253007</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140823063212/http://profiles.nlm.nih.gov/SC/B/B/Y/W/_/scbbyw.pdf" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> <span class="cs1-format">(PDF)</span> from the original on 23 August 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-Pearson_2006-62"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Pearson_2006_62-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Pearson_2006_62-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFPearson2006">Pearson, Helen (25 May 2006). <li id="cite_note-Laland06-71"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Laland06_71-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLalandSterelny2006">Laland, Kevin N.; <li id="cite_note-79"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-79">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHastingsLupskiRosenbergIra2009">Hastings, P. <li id="cite_note-88"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-88">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLongBetránThorntonWang2003">Long, Manyuan; Betrán, Esther; Thornton, Kevin; Wang, Wen (November 2003). "The origin of new genes: glimpses from the young and old". <i>Nature Reviews Genetics</i>. <b>4</b> (11): 865–875. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fnrg1204" rel="nofollow">10.1038/nrg1204</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1471-0056" rel="nofollow">1471-0056</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/14634634" rel="nofollow">14634634</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:33999892" rel="nofollow">33999892</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature+Reviews+Genetics&amp;rft.atitle=The+origin+of+new+genes%3A+glimpses+from+the+young+and+old&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=11&amp;rft.pages=865-875&amp;rft.date=2003-11&amp;rft.issn=1471-0056&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A33999892%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F14634634&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnrg1204&amp;rft.aulast=Long&amp;rft.aufirst=Manyuan&amp;rft.au=Betr%C3%A1n%2C+Esther&amp;rft.au=Thornton%2C+Kevin&amp;rft.au=Wang%2C+Wen&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-89"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-89">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWangCaetano-Anollés2009">Wang, Minglei; <a href="/wiki/Gustavo_Caetano-Anolles" title="Gustavo Caetano-Anolles">Caetano-Anollés, Gustavo</a> (14 January 2009). <li id="cite_note-parasite-99"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-parasite_99-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFHamiltonAxelrodTanese1990"><a href="/wiki/W._D._Hamilton" title="W. D.</a>; <a href="/wiki/Robert_Axelrod" title="Robert Axelrod">Axelrod, Robert</a>; Tanese, Reiko (1 May 1990). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC53943" rel="nofollow">"Sexual reproduction as an adaptation to resist parasites (a review)"</a>. <i>Proc. </li>
<li id="cite_note-119"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-119">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFTomićMeyer-Rochow2011">Tomić, Nenad; <li id="cite_note-129"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-129">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLienSzydaSchechingerRappold2000">Lien, Sigbjørn; Szyda, Joanna; Schechinger, Birgit;  et al. </li>

<li id="cite_note-138"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-138">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLande1989">Lande, Russell (1989). <a class="external text" href="https://archive.org/details/sim_genome_1989_31_1/page/221" rel="nofollow">"Fisherian and Wrightian theories of speciation"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/Genome_(journal)" title="Genome (journal)">Genome</a></i>. <b>31</b> (1): 221–227. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1139%2Fg89-037" rel="nofollow">10.1139/g89-037</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0831-2796" rel="nofollow">0831-2796</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2687093" rel="nofollow">2687093</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Genome&amp;rft.atitle=Fisherian+and+Wrightian+theories+of+speciation&amp;rft.volume=31&amp;rft.issue=1&amp;rft.pages=221-227&amp;rft.date=1989&amp;rft.issn=0831-2796&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F2687093&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1139%2Fg89-037&amp;rft.aulast=Lande&amp;rft.aufirst=Russell&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Farchive.org%2Fdetails%2Fsim_genome_1989_31_1%2Fpage%2F221&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-146"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-146">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMuñoz-GómezBilolikarWidemanGeiler-Samerotte2021">Muñoz-Gómez, Sergio A.; Bilolikar, Gaurav; Wideman, Jeremy G.; Geiler-Samerotte, Kerry (1 April 2021). <a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007/s00239-021-09996-y" rel="nofollow">"Constructive Neutral Evolution 20 Years Later"</a>. <i>Journal of Molecular Evolution</i>. <b>89</b> (3): 172–182. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2021JMolE..89..172M" rel="nofollow">2021JMolE..89..172M</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1007%2Fs00239-021-09996-y" rel="nofollow">10.1007/s00239-021-09996-y</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1432-1432" rel="nofollow">1432-1432</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7982386" rel="nofollow">7982386</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33604782" rel="nofollow">33604782</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20220730090616/https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s00239-021-09996-y" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 30 July 2022<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-154">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" <ul><li><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1">Nei, Masatoshi (May 2006). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1513187" rel="nofollow">"Selectionism and Neutralism in Molecular Evolution"</a>. <i>Molecular Biology and Evolution</i> (Erratum). <b>23</b> (5): 2318–42. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1093%2Fmolbev%2Fmsk009" rel="nofollow">10.1093/molbev/msk009</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0737-4038" rel="nofollow">0737-4038</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1513187" rel="nofollow">1513187</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16120807" rel="nofollow">16120807</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Molecular+Biology+and+Evolution&amp;rft.atitle=Selectionism+and+Neutralism+in+Molecular+Evolution&amp;rft.volume=23&amp;rft.issue=5&amp;rft.pages=2318-42&amp;rft.date=2006-05&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC1513187%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft.issn=0737-4038&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F16120807&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1093%2Fmolbev%2Fmsk009&amp;rft.aulast=Nei&amp;rft.aufirst=Masatoshi&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC1513187&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></li></ul>

<li id="cite_note-ShahGilchrist2011-163"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-ShahGilchrist2011_163-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFShahGilchrist2011">Shah, Premal; Gilchrist, Michael A. U.S.A</i>. <b>108</b> (25): 10231–10236. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2011PNAS..10810231S" rel="nofollow">2011PNAS..10810231S</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1073%2Fpnas.1016719108" rel="nofollow">10.1073/pnas.1016719108</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3121864" rel="nofollow">3121864</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21646514" rel="nofollow">21646514</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Proc.+Natl.+Acad.+Sci.+U.S.A.&amp;rft.atitle=Explaining+complex+codon+usage+patterns+with+selection+for+translational+efficiency%2C+mutation+bias%2C+and+genetic+drift&amp;rft.volume=108&amp;rft.issue=25&amp;rft.pages=10231-10236&amp;rft.date=2011-06-21&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3121864%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F21646514&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1073%2Fpnas.1016719108&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2011PNAS..10810231S&amp;rft.aulast=Shah&amp;rft.aufirst=Premal&amp;rft.au=Gilchrist%2C+Michael+A.&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC3121864&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Payne2019-171"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Payne2019_171-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFPayneMenardoTraunerBorrell2019">Payne, Joshua L.; Menardo, Fabrizio; Trauner, Andrej;  et al. <li id="cite_note-Storz2019-172"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Storz2019_172-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFStorzNatarajanSignoreWitt2019">Storz, Jay F.; Natarajan, Chandrasekhar; Signore, Anthony V.;  et al. <li id="cite_note-185"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-185">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWhitmanColemanWiebe1998">Whitman, William B.; Coleman, David C.; Wiebe, William J. <li id="cite_note-189"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-189">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFElenaLenski2003">Elena, Santiago F.; <a href="/wiki/Richard_Lenski" title="Richard Lenski">Lenski, Richard E.</a> (June 2003). "Evolution experiments with microorganisms: the dynamics and genetic bases of adaptation". <i>Nature Reviews Genetics</i>. <b>4</b> (6): 457–469. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fnrg1088" rel="nofollow">10.1038/nrg1088</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1471-0056" rel="nofollow">1471-0056</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12776215" rel="nofollow">12776215</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:209727" rel="nofollow">209727</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature+Reviews+Genetics&amp;rft.atitle=Evolution+experiments+with+microorganisms%3A+the+dynamics+and+genetic+bases+of+adaptation&amp;rft.volume=4&amp;rft.issue=6&amp;rft.pages=457-469&amp;rft.date=2003-06&amp;rft.issn=1471-0056&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A209727%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F12776215&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnrg1088&amp;rft.aulast=Elena&amp;rft.aufirst=Santiago+F.&amp;rft.au=Lenski%2C+Richard+E.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-190"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-190">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFMayr1982">Mayr 1982</a>, p. 483: "Adaptation... could no longer be considered a static condition, a product of a creative past and became instead a continuing dynamic process."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-191"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-191">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The sixth edition of the <i>Oxford Dictionary of Science</i> (2010) defines <i>adaptation</i> as "Any change in the structure or functioning of successive generations of a population that makes it better suited to its environment."</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-192"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-192">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFOrr2005">Orr, H. Allen (February 2005). "The genetic theory of adaptation: a brief history". <i>Nature Reviews Genetics</i>. <b>6</b> (2): 119–127. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1038%2Fnrg1523" rel="nofollow">10.1038/nrg1523</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1471-0056" rel="nofollow">1471-0056</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15716908" rel="nofollow">15716908</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/S2CID_(identifier)" title="S2CID (identifier)">S2CID</a> <a class="external text" href="https://api.semanticscholar.org/CorpusID:17772950" rel="nofollow">17772950</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Nature+Reviews+Genetics&amp;rft.atitle=The+genetic+theory+of+adaptation%3A+a+brief+history&amp;rft.volume=6&amp;rft.issue=2&amp;rft.pages=119-127&amp;rft.date=2005-02&amp;rft.issn=1471-0056&amp;rft_id=https%3A%2F%2Fapi.semanticscholar.org%2FCorpusID%3A17772950%23id-name%3DS2CID&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F15716908&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1038%2Fnrg1523&amp;rft.aulast=Orr&amp;rft.aufirst=H.+Allen&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-193"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-193">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDobzhansky1968">Dobzhansky 1968</a>, pp. 1–34</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-194"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-194">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDobzhansky1970">Dobzhansky 1970</a>, pp. 4–6, 79–82, 84–87</span>
</li>

<li id="cite_note-204"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-204">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFMaselBergman2003">Masel, Joanna; <li id="cite_note-Fong-212"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Fong_212-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Fong_212-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-Fong_212-2"><sup><i><b>c</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFFongKaneCulver1995">Fong, Daniel F.; Kane, Thomas C.; Culver, David C. "Vestigialization and Loss of Nonfunctional Characters". <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Ecology_and_Systematics" title="Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics">Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics</a></i>. <b>26</b>: 249–268. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1146%2Fannurev.es.26.110195.001341" rel="nofollow">10.1146/annurev.es.26.110195.001341</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1545-2069" rel="nofollow">1545-2069</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Annual+Review+of+Ecology+and+Systematics&amp;rft.atitle=Vestigialization+and+Loss+of+Nonfunctional+Characters&amp;rft.volume=26&amp;rft.pages=249-268&amp;rft.date=1995-11&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1146%2Fannurev.es.26.110195.001341&amp;rft.issn=1545-2069&amp;rft.aulast=Fong&amp;rft.aufirst=Daniel+F.&amp;rft.au=Kane%2C+Thomas+C.&amp;rft.au=Culver%2C+David+C.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-226"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-226">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFPiatigorskyKantorowGopal-SrivastavaTomarev1994">Piatigorsky et al. 1994</a>, pp. 241–250</span>

<li id="cite_note-234"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-234">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFGeffeneyBrodieRubenBrodie2002">Geffeney, Shana; Brodie, Edmund D. <li id="cite_note-241"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-241">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFWilsonHölldobler2005">Wilson, Edward O.; Hölldobler, Bert (20 September 2005). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1224642" rel="nofollow">"Eusociality: Origin and consequences"</a>. <i>Proc. <li id="cite_note-250"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-250">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFVrijenhoek2006">Vrijenhoek, Robert C. <li id="cite_note-251"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-251">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFRiceHostert1993">Rice, William R.; Hostert, Ellen E. (December 1993). <li id="cite_note-255"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-255">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFTempleton1980"><a href="/wiki/Alan_Templeton" title="Alan Templeton">Templeton, Alan R.</a> (April 1980). <a class="external text" href="http://www.genetics.org/content/94/4/1011.full.pdf+html" rel="nofollow">"The Theory of Speciation <i>VIA</i> the Founder Principle"</a>. <i>Genetics</i>. <b>94</b> (4): 1011–1038. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1093%2Fgenetics%2F94.4.1011" rel="nofollow">10.1093/genetics/94.4.1011</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0016-6731" rel="nofollow">0016-6731</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1214177" rel="nofollow">1214177</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6777243" rel="nofollow">6777243</a>. <a class="external text" href="https://web.archive.org/web/20140823063455/http://www.genetics.org/content/94/4/1011.full.pdf+html" rel="nofollow">Archived</a> from the original on 23 August 2014<span class="reference-accessdate">. <li id="cite_note-256"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-256">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFAntonovics2006"><a href="/wiki/Janis_Antonovics" title="Janis Antonovics">Antonovics, Janis</a> (July 2006). </li>
<li id="cite_note-257"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-257">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFNosilCrespiGriesGries2007">Nosil, Patrik; <li id="cite_note-262"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-262">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFJakobssonHagenbladTavaréSäll2006">Jakobsson, Mattias; Hagenblad, Jenny; <a href="/wiki/Simon_Tavar%C3%A9" title="Simon Tavaré">Tavaré, Simon</a>;  et al. <li id="cite_note-263"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-263">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSällJakobssonLind-HalldénHalldén2003">Säll, Torbjörn; Jakobsson, Mattias; Lind-Halldén, Christina; Halldén, Christer (September 2003). </li>
<li id="cite_note-264"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-264">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBombliesWeigel2007"><a href="/wiki/Kirsten_Bomblies" title="Kirsten Bomblies">Bomblies, Kirsten</a>; <a href="/wiki/Detlef_Weigel" title="Detlef Weigel">Weigel, Detlef</a> (December 2007). <li id="cite_note-273"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-273">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBarnoskyKochFeranecWing2004"><a href="/wiki/Anthony_David_Barnosky" title="Anthony David Barnosky">Barnosky, Anthony D.</a>; Koch, Paul L.; Feranec, Robert S.;  et al. <li id="cite_note-285"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-285">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFSchouten2015">Schouten, Lucy (20 October 2015). <a class="external text" href="https://www.csmonitor.com/Science/2015/1020/When-did-life-first-emerge-on-Earth-Maybe-a-lot-earlier-than-we-thought" rel="nofollow">"When did life first emerge on Earth? Maybe a lot earlier than we thought"</a>. <i><a href="/wiki/The_Christian_Science_Monitor" title="The Christian Science Monitor">The Christian Science Monitor</a></i>. <li id="cite_note-298"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-298">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><a href="#CITEREFDarwin1859">Darwin 1859</a>, p. <a class="external text" href="http://darwin-online.org.uk/content/frameset?itemID=F373&amp;viewtype=text&amp;pageseq=16" rel="nofollow">1</a></span>

<li id="cite_note-299"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-299">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFDoolittleBapteste2007">Doolittle, W. Ford; Bapteste, Eric (13 February 2007). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1892968" rel="nofollow">"Pattern pluralism and the Tree of Life hypothesis"</a>. <i>Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A</i>. <b>104</b> (7): 2043–2049. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bibcode_(identifier)" title="Bibcode (identifier)">Bibcode</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2007PNAS..104.2043D" rel="nofollow">2007PNAS..104.2043D</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1073%2Fpnas.0610699104" rel="nofollow">10.1073/pnas.0610699104</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/0027-8424" rel="nofollow">0027-8424</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1892968" rel="nofollow">1892968</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17261804" rel="nofollow">17261804</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Proc.+Natl.+Acad.+Sci.+U.S.A.&amp;rft.atitle=Pattern+pluralism+and+the+Tree+of+Life+hypothesis&amp;rft.volume=104&amp;rft.issue=7&amp;rft.pages=2043-2049&amp;rft.date=2007-02-13&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC1892968%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft_id=info%3Abibcode%2F2007PNAS..104.2043D&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F17261804&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1073%2Fpnas.0610699104&amp;rft.issn=0027-8424&amp;rft.aulast=Doolittle&amp;rft.aufirst=W.+Ford&amp;rft.au=Bapteste%2C+Eric&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC1892968&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-Cavalier-Smith-307"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-Cavalier-Smith_307-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a </li>
<li id="cite_note-308"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-308">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFSchopf2006">Schopf, J. <li id="cite_note-314"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-314">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFDeLongPace2001"><a href="/wiki/Edward_DeLong" title="Edward DeLong">DeLong, Edward F.</a>; <a href="/wiki/Norman_R._Pace" title="Norman R. <li id="cite_note-315"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-315">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFKaiser2001"><a href="/wiki/A._Dale_Kaiser" title="A. </li>
<li id="cite_note-NYT-20160107-316"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-NYT-20160107_316-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation news cs1" id="CITEREFZimmer2016"><a href="/wiki/Carl_Zimmer" title="Carl Zimmer">Zimmer, Carl</a> (7 January 2016). <a class="external text" href="https://www.nytimes.com/2016/01/12/science/genetic-flip-helped-organisms-go-from-one-cell-to-many.html" rel="nofollow">"Genetic Flip Helped Organisms Go From One Cell to Many"</a>. <i>The New York Times</i>. <li id="cite_note-Bull-324"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-Bull_324-0">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFBullWichman2001"><a href="/wiki/James_J._Bull" title="James J. "Applied evolution". <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Ecology_and_Systematics" title="Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics">Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics</a></i>. <b>32</b>: 183–217. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1146%2Fannurev.ecolsys.32.081501.114020" rel="nofollow">10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.32.081501.114020</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1545-2069" rel="nofollow">1545-2069</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=Annual+Review+of+Ecology+and+Systematics&amp;rft.atitle=Applied+evolution&amp;rft.volume=32&amp;rft.pages=183-217&amp;rft.date=2001-11&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1146%2Fannurev.ecolsys.32.081501.114020&amp;rft.issn=1545-2069&amp;rft.aulast=Bull&amp;rft.aufirst=James+J.&amp;rft.au=Wichman%2C+Holly+A.&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>

<li id="cite_note-333"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-333">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1067248974" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><cite class="citation journal cs1" id="CITEREFLabbéBerticatBerthomieuUnal2007">Labbé, Pierrick; Berticat, Claire; Berthomieu, Arnaud;  et al. (16 November 2007). <a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2077897" rel="nofollow">"Forty Years of Erratic Insecticide Resistance Evolution in the Mosquito <i>Culex pipiens</i>"</a>. <i>PLOS Genetics</i>. <b>3</b> (11): e205. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Doi_(identifier)" title="Doi (identifier)">doi</a>:<a class="external text" href="https://doi.org/10.1371%2Fjournal.pgen.0030205" rel="nofollow">10.1371/journal.pgen.0030205</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISSN_(identifier)" title="ISSN (identifier)">ISSN</a> <a class="external text" href="//www.worldcat.org/issn/1553-7390" rel="nofollow">1553-7390</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMC_(identifier)" title="PMC (identifier)">PMC</a> <span class="cs1-lock-free" title="Freely accessible"><a class="external text" href="//www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2077897" rel="nofollow">2077897</a></span>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/PMID_(identifier)" title="PMID (identifier)">PMID</a> <a class="external text" href="//pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18020711" rel="nofollow">18020711</a>.</cite><span class="Z3988" title="ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&amp;rft.genre=article&amp;rft.jtitle=PLOS+Genetics&amp;rft.atitle=Forty+Years+of+Erratic+Insecticide+Resistance+Evolution+in+the+Mosquito+Culex+pipiens&amp;rft.volume=3&amp;rft.issue=11&amp;rft.pages=e205&amp;rft.date=2007-11-16&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2077897%23id-name%3DPMC&amp;rft.issn=1553-7390&amp;rft_id=info%3Apmid%2F18020711&amp;rft_id=info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pgen.0030205&amp;rft.aulast=Labb%C3%A9&amp;rft.aufirst=Pierrick&amp;rft.au=Berticat%2C+Claire&amp;rft.au=Berthomieu%2C+Arnaud&amp;rft.au=Unal%2C+Sandra&amp;rft.au=Bernard%2C+Clothilde&amp;rft.au=Weill%2C+Myl%C3%A8ne&amp;rft.au=Lenormand%2C+Thomas&amp;rft_id=%2F%2Fwww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov%2Fpmc%2Farticles%2FPMC2077897&amp;rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fen.wikipedia.org%3AEvolution"></span></span>
